lead_paragraph: WHY GO NOW -- When summer comes to Seattle, blinking residents emerge from bookstores and coffeehouses, shrug off their rubberized rain jackets, chrysalis-like, and change into cycling shorts, then rock-climbing shoes, and finally strappy sandals for a night on the town. (Call it the Seattle triathlon.) From July through September -- the dry months in this notoriously wet city -- Seattle hums with a manic energy as residents try to shoehorn as much outdoor fun as possible into those precious, long-lingering summer days. The best way to enjoy Seattle in summer is to follow their lead: chase a peloton of road cyclists, join the flotilla of boats on Lake Washington or simply spread a picnic blanket on the beach at Golden Gardens and watch the Japan-bound sun torch the sky over Puget Sound. WHERE TO STAY -- For those tired of the same bland hotel experience Acadia Houseboat Rentals, 2040 Westlake Avenue North, (206) 200-8636 and www.seattlehouseboatrentals.com, rents five houseboats on the west side of Lake Union, about five minutes from the heart of downtown. The boats, which sleep four to six, are not hugely roomy. But the pleasure in staying on one is to sit on deck with a cup of strong Seattle coffee and watch floatplanes take off for their morning run to the San Juan Islands. Rates are $140 to $220 a night.

That is to attend the Seattle Opera's greatly acclaimed production of the ''Ring'' cycle, a musical event of national significance.

lead_paragraph: The Basics -- Seattle seems to have almost as many hotels as it has Starbucks. From my window, on the 10th floor of the Ändra, the Westin (a pair of round skyscrapers) dominates the skyline. For those who want to avoid large convention hotels, boutique-style offerings include a handsome W and the Monaco (part of the Kimpton chain of quirky small hotels). The Ändra, which opened in April 2004, is less chic than the W, less offbeat than the Monaco and less expensive than either. The Rooms -- In a city where Rem Koolhaas's Seattle Public Library has raised the architectural bar, the kind of earth-tone-modern look that the Ändra goes for (beige walls, wenge-wood furniture and charcoal-colored bedspreads) seems almost passé. There are several nice touches, however. A Tivoli clock radio -- a device with a retro look but high-tech guts -- provides a terrific sound. And there's a coffee maker -- practically unheard of in a hotel that also offers room service breakfast. I stowed a container of milk in my minibar refrigerator the night before, and I was good to go. But the reading lamps are angled incorrectly and have blue-glass shades, which cast a peculiar light. The TV is huge, and dominates the dresser. Windows open from the bottom (which is only about 20 inches off the floor), and there are no child guards -- which, even if legal, seems unwise. The entire hotel is nonsmoking. The Bathroom -- Like the bedroom, it feels like an old room that's been modernized, but inconsistently. (The sink, for some reason, is an imitation Victorian pedestal model.) Happily, the toilet is a Flushometer, the tankless type that ''whooshes'' -- and is practically impossible to clog. But whoever had the idea of shrink-wrapping individual bars of soap (the case in more and more hotels) needs a new job; I had to leave the bathroom and use the knife from a room service tray to unwrap the small bar (made by Face Stockholm). There were also a couple of (minor) housekeeping glitches. The Location -- Fourth Avenue is a prime Seattle address. Rem Koolhaas's library is on Fourth, as are the Monaco and W hotels (in the heart of downtown). The Ändra is at the north end of downtown, at the beginning of Belltown, a neighborhood distinguished by one thing: the presence of a red banner on every lamppost that says ''Belltown''. The attractions of the Seattle Center -- including the Space Needle and the Seattle Repertory Theater -- are nearby. So are some of the city's best restaurants, including the dazzling Lampreia. Amenities -- The health club is literally a hotel room (No. 309), with three machines and a single bench for lifting. But there's also an arrangement with a nearby sports club. Day passes are available at the hotel for $12. The hotel's restaurant, Lola, serves a smart array of Greek-inspired food (like kebab of squid, crushed chili and chermoula, a Moroccan marinade). Mobbed on a Friday night, it is one of four popular Seattle outposts of the star chef Tom Douglas. Most annoying amenity: TV's, which were tuned to CNBC, in the elevators. Room service -- Pretty much the Lola menu. At bedtime, a pie of goat's milk custard with orange caramel sauce and sour cherries ($8) was unusual and delicious. The next morning, breakfast, ordered at 9:05, arrived at 9:20. The Greek yogurt with granola and fresh fruit ($10) was the Platonic ideal of a healthy breakfast. Order toast ($5), without specifying a type, and you get crunchy, delicious sourdough, straight from Tom Douglas's bakery across the street. The Bottom Line -- A standard room is $189. In a city with lots of hotels, the Ändra adds an enjoyable, medium-price option. Hotel Ändra is at 2000 Fourth Avenue; (877) 448-8600; www.hotelandra.com. FRED A. BERNSTEIN

lead_paragraph: The necklace of lakes and waterways that surround and flow through this city are giant playgrounds at this time of year as Seattle's short season of sun is ending. Tall masts rising from docked sailboats clank and chime in the wind, a summer ballad on quiet nights along Lake Washington. Motorboats zoom across Lake Union, ferrying giddy sun worshipers and seafaring sorts who live through months of darkness and rain for these clear but numbered days on the open water.

headline.main: In Boat Haven, Soaring Fuel Costs Bring Subtle Changes

lead_paragraph: A man accused of killing two sex offenders last month after finding their names on a Web site told the police he had been sexually molested as a child and claimed responsibility for the killings on an Internet posting, the authorities said Thursday. The police in Bellingham, Wash., said they believed that the suspect, Michael A. Mullen, 35, was the person who wrote on an America Online personal site, under the alias Agent Life and with grammar mistakes, ''I alone and responsible for the deaths of the two level three pedophiles in Bellingham Washington, and they are not the last to be executed unless things change for the better.'' Level 3 sex offenders are considered at the highest risk of committing another sex crime.

headline.main: Murder Suspect Is Said to Cite His Own Abuse

lead_paragraph: An oversize load moved slowly in the dark through the streets of Seattle and trundled onto the quiet freeways, arriving in this small city 90 minutes later, at dawn on Sunday morning. The load, towed by a tankerlike truck, was filled with rock 'n' roll history and for years was at the center of a bitter battle in Seattle. It was the childhood home of the legendary guitarist Jimi Hendrix, a tiny two-bedroom house, now dilapidated. It is the house where in the mid-1950's, Mr. Hendrix would jump on his bed in the room he shared with his younger brother, Leon, and play air guitar, where he listened to the blues for the first time on borrowed records, and where he obsessively strummed an old one-string ukulele, his brother said.

headline.main: Jimi Hendrix's House Has a New Experience

abstract: Childhood home of legendary guitarist Jimi Hendrix is moved from Seattle to Renton, Wash, after four-year struggle involving protracted court battles with city of Seattle, foundation started by Hendrix's brother Leon Hendrix and Hendrix's fans; new sight for tiny two-bedroom house is in rundown three-acre mobile home park, across street from cemetery where Hendrix is buried; he died at age of 27 in 1970l; photo (M)
snippet: The childhood home of the legendary rock guitarist Jimi Hendrix - a tiny two-bedroom house, now dilapidated - was moved to Renton, Wash.

lead_paragraph: Seattle's 17-year ban on new strip clubs has ended after a federal judge ruled that it was illegal and violated the First Amendment. The judge, James L. Robart of Federal District Court, ruled on Monday that Seattle had effectively created a licensing scheme that restricted the issuing of adult cabaret licenses, amounting to illegal restraint on a legal business. Seattle, which has four strip clubs, tried to justify the ban by arguing that adult dancing was alive and well and that its failure to adopt new legislation was for reasons other than censorship. The city does not plan to appeal the ruling, said Marty McOmber, a spokesman for Mayor Greg Nickels. David Carrillo Peñaloza (NYT)

lead_paragraph: LET'S face it. Wine tastings and sake bars have their merits, but a hoot and a holler they're not. You're dying for a beer -- just a nice, cold, frothy mug, a wooden bench and some good old-fashioned hedonism. Enter the Oktoberfest -- that glorious 16-day excuse to eat, drink, dance and frolic to heart's content. This month, millions will descend on an open field in Munich to celebrate at the original stomping grounds of King Maximilian, whose wedding reception for his son began the tradition of Oktoberfest in 1810. Back in North America, cities like Cincinnati; La Crosse, Wis.; and the communities of Kitchener and Waterloo, Ontario, will entertain hundreds of thousands with their spot-on renditions of the German festival. But other places are putting their own spin on this venerable tradition.

lead_paragraph: The Seattle City Council withdrew its support of the Seattle Monorail in a vote that all but kills the transit project. In a unanimous vote, the nine-member Council passed a resolution saying the city would deny street-use permits for the monorail's proposed 14-mile Green Line. In June, the board of the Seattle Monorail Project revealed that building the line -- from West Seattle through downtown to the Ballard neighborhood on the city's north side -- would cost more than $11 billion over 50 years, more than four times the project's estimated cost.

Kirshenbaum (NYT)

lead_paragraph: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES knows a good opportunity when it sees one. The airline's attempted move to Seattle's smallish Boeing Field from the newer Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, known as Sea-Tac, was going to be just one more victory for Southwest. But last week, opposition from neighborhood and business groups in Seattle stopped the airline as it tried to follow its proven strategy of using older, regional airports to slash costs and reel in customers happy to shave 15 or more minutes of travel time from their trips to the airport.

headline.main: The Little Airport That Said No to Southwest

snippet: Southwest Airlines attempted move to a smaller airport was thwarted by opposition from neighborhood and business groups.

lead_paragraph: In Shaun Alexander's world, there is no wall between church and work. The Bible is his playbook, in life and on the football field. ''Every morning I wake up, I'm chasing God,'' he said, and he still manages to mix in an occasional juke and jitterbug. Alexander, the sixth-year Seattle Seahawks running back, leads the National Football League in rushing and in touchdowns. He also prays with and ministers to his teammates as well as to youth at his church.

headline.main: Faith Is No Guarantee

snippet: Shaun Alexander, the Seattle Seahawks running back, leads the N.F.L. in rushing and touchdowns. He also ministers to his teammates and to youth at his church.

There are at least 21 dialects spoken in the highlands, and the festival is a potpourri of folk music, arts, colorful traditional dress and an especially vibrant crafts market.

lead_paragraph: When Giants punter Jeff Feagles steps onto the field Sunday in Seattle, he will be recognized more for what he did not do during an 18-year career than for anything else. He has never missed a game. Feagles is expected to play in his 283rd consecutive regular-season game, breaking the National Football League record set by Jim Marshall, a former Vikings defensive lineman. Consecutive-game streaks are considered major individual records in the N.F.L., the National Basketball Association, Major League Baseball and the National Hockey League.

headline.main: 282 Games, 1,410 Punts And No Rest For Feagles

lead_paragraph: The Seahawks, playing poorly for much of the past couple of decades, have not drawn considerable attention beyond the Northwest. But they appear to be on the verge of changing that. With their 24-21 overtime victory over the Giants on Sunday, they improved to 9-2 for the best record in the National Football Conference. It was the Seahawks' seventh consecutive victory, the franchise's longest winning streak since the team won eight in a row in 1984, the last season Seattle won a playoff game.

headline.main: With Jurevicius' Help, Seahawks Shed Past

lead_paragraph: For a while, Gabe Klein could easily keep track of every car in his territory simply by sticking pins on the wall-size map of the Washington metropolitan area in his office. No longer. ''It was nice to have a visual on the wall when we had 25 or 30 cars, but not with 200 cars in 130 locations,'' said Mr. Klein, a regional vice president for ZipCar, one of two companies trying to succeed at providing a relatively new service of short-term auto rentals in urban centers.

headline.main: By the Hour, Your Chariot Awaits; A Few Keyboard Clicks Put Car Sharers on Wheels

lead_paragraph: In Sedum, Less Can Be More Q. Most of the Sedum spurium in my Seattle garden is thriving and blooming. But in a few places it looks straggly and weak. Should I cut it all back or just prune the bad patches? A. Pruning will strengthen weak sedums if all that is wrong is neglect. And thriving plants can be left alone. But you will get the most uniform carpet if you remove old growth from all the plants. Wait until flowering is finished, and then clip away everything except healthy stems rising directly from the soil.

headline.main: GARDEN Q. & A.

snippet: Most of the Sedum spurium in my garden is thriving and blooming. But in a few places it looks straggly and weak. Should I cut it all back or just prune the bad patches?

lead_paragraph: A plant to turn radioactive waste from the Hanford nuclear weapons installation into glasslike logs could cost billions of dollars more than first estimated and take an additional four years to build, The Seattle Times reported. According to an Army Corps of Engineers report, completed in May, the cost could soar to $9.65 billion from $5.8 billion, and the project might not be completed until 2015, the newspaper said. The Energy Department has refused to release the report or a new cost estimate or schedule. The Times said a copy was leaked to it.

''This really makes me feel like a second-class citizen,'' said Matt Fischer, shivering along with the others in the Smoke Shack, as the bar calls its tarp-enclosed area.

headline.main: Smokers Fret, Others Cheer, Over New Ban In Northwest

snippet: The ban says no smoking within 25 feet of public places in Seattle.

lead_paragraph: It is not uncommon for academic institutions to dabble in real estate investments, but the University of Washington's nest egg is unusual -- 11 acres in the heart of the city's downtown, about five miles from its campus. Over the last half-century, rental income generated by this site has played a major role in the development of U.W., one of the state's largest employers. Proceeds from this downtown property, known as Metropolitan Tract, are being used, for example, to repay $44.8 million in construction bonds for William H. Gates Hall, a glassy building that houses the university's law school; it is named for the father of Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft. Private funds made up less than half of the cost.

headline.main: An Unusual Higher Education Moneymaker

snippet: Rental of 11 acres in the heart of downtown Seattle earns millions for the University of Washington.

lead_paragraph: AFTER nine years in Seattle, Mark Marvel was more than ready to come home to New York. Seattle was too homogeneous, too provincial and too rainy for his taste, he said. The longer he lived there, the more he craved New York. He hoped to return at some point, or at least to become fully bicoastal.

headline.main: Jumping at the Chance to Return to New York

snippet: Mark Marvel had a career in Seattle, but his heart was in New York. Now both are in the same place, in an apartment he bought in Dumbo for $790,000.

lead_paragraph: IF housing prices in your neighborhood are too high, how about something for a dollar? When Kingman Ho, a physician, bought a 1,000-square-foot 1960's house in Seattle's Mount Baker neighborhood in May, the sellers figured he would tear it down. But Dr. Ho was so intrigued by some of the house's quirky features, like a child's playpen that converts to a conversation pit for grown-ups, that he devised a way to try to save it.

headline.main: That Tear-Down Could Be a Haul-Away

snippet: Today owners who admire midcentury architecture are finding ways to save the buildings.

lead_paragraph: The culprits were not after cappuccino, but baristas figured prominently in their robbery spree across the Seattle area -- and in their apparent undoing. Baristas at as many as 10 drive-up espresso stands, as ubiquitous here in the nation's coffee capital as McDonald's are, were robbed at gunpoint last month. In each case, less than $200 was taken and the victim was a young woman, the authorities said.

headline.main: Espresso Huts Are Target, And Barista Tips Police

snippet: A fugitive from Brooklyn and a woman from Oklahoma are the prime suspects in a spree of Seattle-area coffee hut holdups.

lead_paragraph: Marcus Hahnemann spends a lot of money on goalie shirts. It is not because he wears only new apparel for each game he plays in goal for Reading in England, but because he tosses his shirt to the club's fans after every game. ''The fans basically love me, and I've had an awesome relationship with them from Day 1,'' Hahnemann, a Seattle native, said last week in a telephone interview from England. ''I've thrown an awful lot of goalkeeper shirts into the stands. As a goalkeeper, you don't always get the press. But it's a bit funny; every time I make a save, they chant: 'U.S.A.! U.S.A.!' They're not doing it because they love America, even though they know how patriotic I am. Maybe it's because my last name is too long for them to come up with a song.''

headline.main: U.S. Goalie Gives Shirt Off His Back

abstract: Reading Royals goalie Marcus Hahnemann, from Seattle (Wash), gives fans his jersey after every game (M)
snippet: Marcus Hahnemann spends a lot of money on goalie shirts because he tosses his shirt to the club's fans after every game.

lead_paragraph: For years, Paul G. Allen was the invisible billionaire here, a tentative tycoon with a yacht longer than the football field where his Seattle Seahawks will play Sunday. But just as the Seahawks have shed years of obscurity in their first shot at the Super Bowl in more than two decades, Mr. Allen's prints appear everywhere as he remakes his hometown into an urban center to match his peripatetic passions.

headline.main: In Seattle, Seahawks Rise, As Does Skyline, in Vision Of a Hometown Tycoon

snippet: Paul G. Allen, the Microsoft billionaire and Seahawks owner, is remaking the city according to his own peripatetic passions.

lead_paragraph: Hours after the Seattle Seahawks' mistake-filled 21-10 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers in the Super Bowl, they were still stuck in frustration. ''We're all a little disappointed this morning,'' Coach Mike Holmgren said yesterday at the team's hotel in suburban Dearborn, Mich., just before leaving for Seattle. ''But I'm very, very proud of our football team, what we accomplished this year. We're going to come back firing away next year.''

headline.main: Seattle Still Feels Sting of Loss

abstract: Seattle Seahawks return to Seattle (Wash) to celebrate franchise-best 15-4 season, despite Super Bowl loss to Pittsburgh Steelers; photo (S)
snippet: Hours after the Seattle Seahawks' mistake-filled 21-10 loss to the Pittsburgh Steelers in the Super Bowl, they were still stuck in frustration.

lead_paragraph: Dave Chappelle Plays The Paramount (Seattle) Dave Chappelle is back, at least for one night. Mr. Chappelle, 32, who walked away from a $50 million contract last year for the third and fourth seasons of his variety show on Comedy Central, has scheduled a standup performance on Sunday night at the Paramount Theater in Seattle, The Associated Press reported. Since he turned his back on the Comedy Central contract, Mr. Chappelle spent two weeks in South Africa amid speculation about his well-being, returned to his farm near Yellow Springs, Ohio, and gave some standup performances. On ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' recently, he said he had fled in part because he felt too many people were trying to control him and his show, and he denied that his departure was prompted by mental or drug problems. Strindberg Painting Stolen A painting by August Strindberg, the Swedish author and an amateur artist, was ripped from a wall in the Strindberg Museum in Stockholm yesterday by a man who sprinted past the receptionist to escape, the museum said. Valued at $1 million by Katarina Ek-Nilsson, right, the museum director, the painting, ''Night of Jealousy,'' is a stormy canvas in blacks and grays. It was one of only three by Strindberg (1849-1912), the author ''Miss Julie'' and ''The Ghost Sonata,'' on view at the small museum. Swedish news reports said that the thief appeared to have two accomplices who distracted museum employees while the painting was taken, but Ms. Ek-Nilsson said she could not confirm that more than one person was involved. Millions Expected For Turner Watercolor A J. M. W. Turner watercolor described as the culmination of his achievement in the medium could fetch more than $3.5 million when it goes to auction at Christie's in London on June 5, the BBC reported. The painting, ''The Blue Rigi: Lake of Lucerne, Sunrise,'' above, was described by the auction house as ''an extraordinary study in light, color and texture.'' The record for a British artwork on paper was set in June 2000, when Dante Gabriel Rossetti's ''Pandora'' was sold for $4.59 million, and the record for a work on paper by Turner was set in 2001 when ''Heidelberg, With a Rainbow'' went for $3.55 million. Footnotes The Broadway run of ''Bridge & Tunnel,'' written and performed by Sarah Jones, has been extended through July 9 at the Helen Hayes Theater. It was scheduled to close on March 12. The extension became possible when Jay Johnson agreed to postpone the opening of ''Jay Johnson: The Two and Only!'' Lord Norman Foster, the British architect, has been chosen to redevelop New Holland, an 18th-century Russian naval base on an island in St. Petersburg, Russia, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. The $320 million project for the ST Group includes a theater, an arena, conference facilities, galleries, shops, apartments and restaurants, according to a statement from Foster & Partners. Two Americans, the tenor Stephen Gould and the soprano Linda Watson, have been chosen for the roles of Siegfried and Brünnhilde in a new production of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle at the Bayreuth Festival in Germany this year, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday. Turner Broadcasting has obtained rights to present the network premiere of Peter Jackson's remake of ''King Kong'' in 2008, Reuters said.

lead_paragraph: There's one, it seems, in every city: the home, once loved and adored, now sits semi-abandoned and unsold, an embarrassment to both its owners and the real-estate agent charged with dispatching what, after an unseemly interval, has come to be known in the business as a white elephant. Maybe the house is priced too high -- eight figures can be steep, even for movie stars and software moguls, even in places like Malibu or Seattle. Maybe a house just needs too much work for its price point.

headline.main: Master Suite, Ocean Views, Harem Room and Piano Bar (Seats 200)

snippet: Some $40 million homes are harder to sell than others.

lead_paragraph: THE painting -- a big, dark cityscape of Seattle as seen from Capital Hill, with Lake Union shining like a whale in the foreground and the hump of Queen Anne Hill rising behind into the belly of a low black cloud -- is so tactile and kinetic it makes you want to touch the paint. And that's exactly what John E. Braseth, co-owner of the Gordon Woodside/John Braseth Gallery in Seattle, does. ''My God, I never noticed those figures in the foreground -- see them on the steps?'' Mr. Braseth is rubbing a thumb over two barely discernible pedestrians on a flight of stairs at the painting's lower left corner.

headline.main: The Mystic Artists: A Puget Sound Quest

snippet: Looking for the Seattle seen by four iconic Northwest painters, local legends known as the "Big Four."

lead_paragraph: A gunman fatally shot six people at a private house party Saturday morning before committing suicide in the worst mass murder in this city in more than two decades, the Seattle police said. The gunman had, like others at the party, attended a ''rave'' concert in the neighborhood and been invited back to the small two-story house in the Capitol Hill neighborhood, said the Seattle police chief, R. Gil Kerlikowske.

headline.main: 7 Dead in Shooting at Seattle House Party

abstract: Gunman fatally shoots six people at private house party before committing suicide in worst mass murder in Seattle in more than 20 years; had attended rave concert earlier with other party-goers; left party briefly at 7 am and returned with shotgun and semi-automatic handgun, which he began firing without warning; police have yet to establish motive; photo (M)
snippet: SEATTLE, March 25  A gunman fatally shot six people at a private house party Saturday morning before committing suicide in the worst mass murder in this city in more than two decades, the Seattle police said.

lead_paragraph: A man suspected of killing six young people at a house party before he turned the gun on himself was identified Sunday by the police as Aaron Kyle Huff, 28. Mr. Huff fatally shot himself on Saturday morning after opening fire on young partygoers who had invited him to a private gathering after a zombie-themed rave, the police said.

headline.main: Suspect Named in Shooting at Seattle Party

abstract: Man suspected of killing six young men and women at house party in Seattle is identified as Aaron Kyle Huff; Huff killed himself after opening fire at party after zombie-themed rave (S)
snippet: The police said they were still trying to determine the motive of a man suspected of killing six young people at a house party before turning the gun on himself.

lead_paragraph: East of the waterfront, up on South Jackson Street, past the International District and at the base of a steep hill in the Central area, looms a giant red Wonder Bread sign. A lonely piece of Americana, the neon sign is perched atop a shuttered bakery in a neighborhood of boarded-up stores and more than a few depressed, empty streets. Beyond the broader neighborhood implications of the factory's imminent demolition and replacement with housing and shops is the prickly question of what happens to the sign.

headline.main: In Seattle, Questions Arise About the Future of a Sign From the Past

abstract: Boarded-up bakery in Seattle's Central area will soon be demolished to make room for housing and shops, and some people are worried about what will become of giant neon Wonder Bread sign perched above it; San Diego company that is developing 1.6-acre property says sign will be donated to nearby Pratt Institute of Fine Arts, but there is concern that Pratt will auction it off piecemeal to wealthy collectors; photos (M)
snippet: A neon Wonder Bread sign perched atop a shuttered bakery about to be demolished has started a debate about preservation.

lead_paragraph: The 28-year-old man who killed six young people at a Seattle house party over the weekend before turning the gun on himself had more than 300 rounds of ammunition and said only one sentence as he carried out the attack, the police said yesterday. ''There's plenty for everyone,'' or something to that effect, was what witnesses told the police the gunman said, Deputy Chief Clark Kimerer of the Seattle Police Department told reporters at a news conference that was streamed over the Internet.

headline.main: Seattle Police and Partygoers Still Puzzle Over Attack

abstract: Seattle police say that Aaron Kyle Huff, 28-year-old gunman who killed six young people at Seattle house party before turning gun on himself, had more than 300 rounds of ammunition; have no idea what motivated Huff (M)
snippet: The man who killed six young people had more than 300 rounds of ammunition and said only one sentence during the attack.

byline.original: By MARIA NEWMAN; Carla Baranauckas contributed reporting for this article

lead_paragraph: The candykids, juggalos, groovers and burners are uniting here with fresh purpose this week. Dancing to the synthesized music that binds them together, planting memorials of candles and their signature beaded bracelets, they join together not to rave, but to mourn slain friends. One woman had a rainbow of yarn woven into her hair. Two men had faces painted in red and black. A man in a suit and tie had a pinkish mohawk. Dozens of others wore baggy clothing or unremarkable dress. All showed up on Tuesday at a spring-green park with a spectacular view of the Space Needle.

headline.main: Seattle's Shattered Rave 'Family' Seeks Answers to Killings

abstract: Rave community mourns six friends who were killed when Aaron Kyle Huff shot and killed them and then himself after zombie-themed rave in Seattle; victims, aged 14 to 32, were familiar faces at spirited parties attended by hundreds in Seattle area; photos (M)
snippet: Mourners remembered slain friends by listening and dancing to the music that had bound them together.

lead_paragraph: Twenty-two Chinese immigrants were in custody Wednesday after they apparently let themselves out of a 40-foot-long cargo container that had been used to smuggle them from China, officials said. The 18 men and 4 women, all believed to be in their 20's and 30's, seemed to be in good physical condition after about two weeks in the container, said Michael Milne, a spokesman for the Customs and Border Protection agency.

headline.main: 22 Chinese Are Held In a Smuggling Case

snippet: The immigrants were in custody in Seattle after they apparently let themselves out of a 40-foot-long cargo container that had been used to smuggle them from China.

lead_paragraph: More than a dozen mayors are to meet at Gracie Mansion next week to discuss ways of stopping illegal gun traffic and reducing gun violence. Mayors Michael R. Bloomberg of New York and Thomas M. Menino of Boston are organizing the meeting, which will be attended by mayors from Seattle, Dallas, Washington, Milwaukee and cities in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Rhode Island.

headline.main: Bloomberg Invites Other Mayors to Town to Discuss Gun Crime

abstract: New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg organizes meeting to discuss illegal gun traffic and violence; Boston Mayor Thomas M Menino is attending along with mayors from across US; Police Commissioner Raymond W Kelly notes that 82% of confiscated guns come from out of New York State; Kelly says meeting is needed to influence legislators; Bloomberg's office will notify unrepresented cities of subjects discussed (M)
snippet: More than a dozen mayors are to meet at Gracie Mansion next week to discuss ways of stopping illegal gun traffic and reducing gun violence.

lead_paragraph: The Chinese president, Hu Jintao, began courting major American business leaders on Tuesday, kicking off a four-day United States tour intended to soothe qualms about China's surging trade surplus and rising political power. Mr. Hu, who on Thursday will make his first visit to the White House since becoming China's top leader more than three years ago, landed in Everett, Wash., north of Seattle, and plunged into meetings with local officials and business executives, including Gov. Chris Gregoire and the Starbucks chairman, Howard D. Schultz.

headline.main: Chinese Leader Focuses on Business as 4-Day U.S. Visit Begins in Washington State

snippet: Chinese President Hu Jintao's tour is intended to soothe qualms about China's surging trade surplus and rising political power.

lead_paragraph: Gamely donning a Boeing baseball cap and mingling enthusiastically with local business executives, President Hu Jintao of China said Wednesday that his nation and the United States ''enjoy extensive common interests'' and could avoid major problems in their relationship if they ''avoid politicizing'' the issues that divide them. Mr. Hu, on the second day of his first visit to the United States as China's top leader, continued a charm offensive directed mainly at commercial interests and offered an overview of economic relations that broke little new ground but displayed a prodigious memory for statistical data.

headline.main: China's Leader, in Seattle, Tells U.S. Not to Dwell on Divisive Issues

snippet: Hu Jintao, on the second day of his first visit to the U.S., continued a charm offensive directed mainly at commercial interests.

byline.original: By JOSEPH KAHN; Leslie Wayne contributed reporting for this article

lead_paragraph: A FOOTLOOSE young American named Jon Rowley sat in a down-at-the-heels room in Paris one day in the mid-1960's, reading ''A Moveable Feast,'' Ernest Hemingway's posthumously published memoir of life in the city during the 1920's. One passage above all seized his attention. Hemingway had written, ''As I ate the oysters with their strong taste of the sea and their faint metallic taste that the cold white wine washed away, leaving only the sea taste and the succulent texture, and as I drank their cold liquid from each shell and washed it down with the crisp taste of the wine, I lost the empty feeling and began to be happy and to make plans.''

headline.main: The Oyster Is His World

abstract: R W Apple Jr article profiles Jon Rowley, expert on and promoter of oysters; Rowley's favorite oyster is found near Puget Sound; different types of oysters described; photos (L)
snippet: After reading Hemingway's "A Moveable Feast," Jon Rowley experienced a kind of epiphany that shaped not only his life but, eventually, the oyster culture of the Pacific Northwest.

lead_paragraph: As a member of the United States Senate, Henry M. Jackson was famous as a cold war hawk who fought for three decades against détente with the Soviet Union. Now, after a nearly quarter-century fight, the University of Washington has decided to display prominently a bronze bust of Mr. Jackson at the school that bears his name.

headline.main: At Namesake Of Senator, His Likeness Gets Its Due

snippet: The University of Washington's bust of Henry M. Jackson, a cold war hawk, had not been displayed prominently because of concern that it might be vandalized.

lead_paragraph: THEY hang inconspicuously behind glass windows just inside the front door of Salumi, a pipsqueak of a place in the shabby Pioneer Square neighborhood of downtown Seattle. Hunks of ruddy-colored meat a little smaller than footballs, trussed with heavy twine, they are easy to miss amid the familiar prosciuttos, salamis and provolone cheeses. But you miss them at your peril. They are princes among pork products, known in northern Italy as the superstars of the antipasto platter, and coveted by generations of big-time eaters in Emilia-Romagna, which harbors more of that species than any other Italian region. Sweeter, mellower and more delicate in flavor than prosciutto, with an astoundingly smooth and creamy texture, these über-hams, called culatelli, have achieved something approaching mythic status among the few Americans lucky enough to have tasted them on their native ground in the foggy Po River lowlands near Parma.

headline.main: A Prince of Pork

abstract: Seattle establishment Salumi carries culatelli, cut of cured pork with near-legendary status; owner Armandino Batalito describes painstaking preparation and curing of meat to achieve prized smooth, creamy texture; photo (M)
snippet: Properly cured culatelli has arrived at last in the United States, courtesy of a cheerful artisan named Armandino Batali.

lead_paragraph: After her father was found to have acute myeloid leukemia, Jorie Lawson felt tormented by well-meaning questions from her classmates in Kingsport, Tenn. How was her dad doing? How was she feeling? School was one place where Jorie, 14, did not want to talk about her father's illness. To give her some peace, Jorie's mother, Kimberly Lawson, recalled, an assistant principal assembled the entire eighth grade in the gym and threatened them with detention if they asked about her father.

His clients include Bill Gates and Bill Clinton, and his elaborate installations of sea gardens and flower clusters show that mere sand transformed by fire can elevate a casino ceiling to the level of gallery spectacle.

lead_paragraph: After nearly a week of protests intended to delay a large Navy cargo ship from sailing to the war in Iraq, the vessel sailed out of Olympia on time Wednesday, port officials said. But the protests, which were raucous at times, could portend a summer of escalating tensions in the port. The police said 20 protesters, most from Evergreen State College here, were arrested earlier in the week on misdemeanor charges of attempted trespass and were then released. Two others were charged with a separate offense stemming from a clash with the police.

headline.main: War Protest Intensifies, But Navy Ship Sails on Time

abstract: US Navy cargo ship Pomeroy, loaded with material for Iraq, sails out of Olympia, Washington, despite several days of protests; 20 protesters, mostly from Evergreen State College, are arrested and released; photos (S)
snippet: A week of protests in Washington State was intended to delay a large cargo ship from sailing to Iraq.

lead_paragraph: NOW that the Supreme Court has agreed to hear two cases challenging racial balancing in public schools, some conservatives hope the end of affirmative action is near. After all, they say, why would the Supreme Court suddenly agree to hear cases about racial balancing in Seattle and Louisville when the court -- with Sandra Day O'Connor still serving -- refused last December to hear a similar case from Massachusetts? It must be, the thinking goes, that the court, with two new and more conservative justices, John G. Roberts Jr. and Samuel A. Alito Jr., wants to overturn affirmative action.

headline.main: Perhaps Not All Affirmative Action Is Created Equal

abstract: Some conservatives hope end of affirmative action is near now that Supreme Court has agreed to hear cases in Seattle and Louisville challenging racial balancing in public schools; optimism may be premature, and not because there is hidden liberal streak on court; there is debate among prominent Republican judges and legal scholars about whether racial balancing in public schools is acceptable form of affirmative action; some conservatives believe that racial balancing plans, while not colorblind, are still constitutional; photo (M)
snippet: A vigorous debate is under way among prominent Republican judges and legal scholars over racial balancing in public schools.

lead_paragraph: School officials in Berkeley, Calif., take race as well as parent income into account as they assign students to public schools, with a result that many black children who live downtown are bused to classes in the mostly white neighborhoods on the hills that overlook San Francisco Bay. In Lynn, Mass., the authorities guarantee that children can attend their neighborhood school, but consider race in weighing students' transfer requests, sometimes blocking those that would increase racial imbalance.

headline.main: Schools' Efforts Hinge on Justices' Ruling in Cases on Race and School Assignments

abstract: Lawyers say that many schools' approaches for maintaining racial diversity could be in jeopardy because of Supreme Court's decision to review cases involving race and school assignment programs in Louisville and Seattle; photos (M)
snippet: Many school districts are awaiting guidance on how far school systems may go in the quest for racial diversity.

byline.original: By SAM DILLON; David M. Herszenhorn contributed reporting from New York for this article

lead_paragraph: It made no sense when Aaron Kyle Huff, a pizza delivery man with a vaporous background, strolled into an early-morning party after a rave in Seattle three months ago and shot eight people at random, killing six before he turned his pistol-grip shotgun on himself. From his hometown of Whitefish, Mont., where Mr. Huff had not made a huge impression despite his bearlike frame, to Seattle, where he lived with his identical twin, the question of ''why'' turned up blank stares and disbelief.

headline.main: After 7 Deaths, Digging for an Explanation

abstract: Seattle Police Chief Gil Kerlikowske has hired Northeastern University criminal justice Prof James Alan Fox to explain why pizza deliveryman Aaron Kyle Huff strolled into early-morning party three months ago and shot eight people at random, killing six before killing himself; Kerlikowske hoped people who would not talk to police might talk to Fox; Fox will present his findings to police in about one week; photos (M)
snippet: Dr. James Alan Fox, who is among the nation's best-known criminologists, has been hired to explain the reasons behind a murder rampage in Seattle.

lead_paragraph: In the midst of its biggest expansion in nearly a decade, the world's largest software company has suddenly found itself with a major setback: not enough room to grow. Microsoft -- in the midst of a bitter rivalry with Google and Yahoo -- snapped into action this April, saying the company would spend about $2 billion on new technologies to reinvigorate itself. Then last month, Microsoft's chairman and co-founder, Bill Gates, announced that he would leave his day-to-day role at the company in two years.

headline.main: Microsoft Is Looking for More Elbow Room

abstract: Microsoft, in midst of its biggest expansion in nearly decade and bitter rivalry with Google and Yahoo, plans to spend $1 billion to expand its sprawling campus in Redmond, Wash, by more than a third, or 3.1 million square feet, over next three years; expansion beyond campus includes new leases and purchase and construction of 14 buildings, including two new buildings in downtown Redmond and new skyscraper in nearby Bellevue; local residents offer mixed reactions to expansion; photos (M)
snippet: A crowded campus and competition have forced the world's largest software company to spend $1 billion over the next three years to expand.

lead_paragraph: Rodney Littlebear was a homeless drunk who for 15 years ran up the public tab with trips to jail, homeless shelters and emergency rooms. He now has a brand-new, government-financed apartment where he can drink as much as he wants. It is part of a first-in-the-nation experiment to ease the torment of drug and alcohol addiction while saving taxpayers' money.

headline.main: Homeless Alcoholics Receive a Permanent Place to Live, and Drink

abstract: Seventy-five street drunks in Seattle are given government-financed housing where they can drink as much as they want; Kings County calculates that public spent $50,000, on average, for each of 40 homeless alcoholics found most often at jail, sobering center and medical center, whereas annual cost for each resident of new facility is expected to be $13,000; critics are incensed that residents do not have to stay sober; Bush administration pledged $2 million toward $11.2 million cost of building; photo (M)
snippet: Government-financed apartments in Seattle aim to ease the torment of addiction while saving taxpayers the cost of trips to jail, homeless shelters and emergency rooms.

lead_paragraph: Five people were injured and one was killed Friday afternoon when a man who expressed anger toward Jews opened fire in the offices of the Jewish Federation of Greater Seattle, the authorities said. The Seattle Police did not identify the suspect. They said he was arrested 12 minutes after the first report came in to emergency dispatchers. At 4:03 p.m., according to Assistant Chief Nick Metz, dispatchers received a call saying people had been shot and hostages taken at the offices of the federation, a fund-raising and planning organization at the edge of downtown.

lead_paragraph: A day after a gunman killed one woman and wounded five others in the offices of the Jewish Federation of Greater Seattle, the police identified a Muslim man on Saturday as the attacker, saying he was angry toward Jews and had used the Internet to select the federation as a random target. As Jewish groups across the Puget Sound region moved to increase security on Saturday, the police identified the suspect as Naveed Afzal Haq, 30, whose family lives in Pasco, in southeast Washington, about 180 miles from Seattle.

lead_paragraph: The parents of a Muslim man accused of shooting to death a woman and injuring five other people at a Jewish nonprofit organization last week wrote letters to Jewish groups on Monday saying ''they don't want this to be seen as anything but the act of an ill person,'' a lawyer for the family said. ''It's basically telling the people that they're very sorry for the tragedy that happened, that they're praying for them,'' said the lawyer, Larry C. Stephenson. ''They don't want this to be seen as creating any hatred between Jewish and Muslim people. The Haqs are very religious people.''

lead_paragraph: The man accused in Friday's shooting rampage at the Jewish Federation office in Seattle that left one woman dead was charged with nine felony counts, including violation of the state's hate-crime law. The man, Naveed Afzal Haq, is charged with aggravated first-degree murder in the death of Pamela Waechter, 58. Five other women were wounded. Charges also include attempted murder, kidnapping and burglary.
