lead_paragraph: Gregory Requa is not the annoying young man caught on camera making rabbit ears and thrusting his hips behind Joyce Mong's back. Nor is he the student who admitted to secretly filming Ms. Mong's English class at Kentridge High School to mock its clutter, her hygiene and to capture the teacher at unbecoming angles. Those two students have completed their punishment. Now, while Mr. Requa still denies any role in making the film or posting it online, it appears he also will serve his time.

headline.main: Court Upholds Suspension Of Student In Video Case

abstract: Judge Marsha J Pechman upholds 40-day suspension Gregory Requa received for his part in making video mocking female teacher at high school outside Seattle and posting it on YouTube and MySpace; he denied involvement and took freedom of speech claim to federal court to seek an injunction of his punishment; school district contends suspension was imposed not because students made video, but because what it depicted amounted to sexual harassment (M)
snippet: A judge has upheld the 40-day suspension a student received because of a video of his teacher which was posted on YouTube.

lead_paragraph: A man accused of shooting six women, one fatally, at a Jewish center in Seattle pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity as prosecutors added 11 counts against him. The man, Naveed Afzal Haq, 31, has a history of mental illness and had pleaded not guilty after the July 28 shooting at the center, the Jewish Federation of Greater Seattle. But at a King County Superior Court hearing, Mr. Haq changed his plea for the 20 charges he now faces. He was charged with aggravated murder, attempted murder, kidnapping and one count each of burglary and malicious harassment, the state's hate-crime law. Prosecutors added a charge of unlawful imprisonment and five counts each of burglary and malicious harassment

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Insanity Plea In Center Shootings

abstract: Naveed Afzal Haq, man accused of shooting six women, one fatally, at Jewish Federation of Greater Seattle, changes plea and pleads not guilty by reason of insanity as prosecutors add 11 counts against him; he now faces 20 charges; Haq has history of mental illness; photo (S)
snippet: A man accused of shooting six women, one fatally, at a Jewish center in Seattle pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity as prosecutors added 11 counts against him.

lead_paragraph: NINE flying white Ford Tauruses, intertwined with ribbons of light and hovering inside a gallery space went on display recently at the Seattle Art Museum (seattleartmuseum.org). They are part of an art piece by Cai Guo-Qiang, the Chinese artist who lives in New York City, called ''Inopportune: Stage One.'' The same piece had been installed at the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art. There is an ambiguity to the piece: Is that nine separate white Tauruses or a representation of one Taurus captured time-lapse-photo style at nine different moments? (Nine lives? One cat?) There is a hint in the fact that these are second generation Tauruses from the 1990s, not the new Taurus, which used to be the Five Hundred. It recalls other artworks using full-size automobiles like Damián Ortega's exploded view of a VW Beetle.

headline.main: A Constellation Of Tauruses

abstract: Nine Tauruses are part of art piece by Cai Guo-Qiang at Seattle Art Museum; photos (M)
snippet: HIGH BEAMS.

lead_paragraph: CONSTRUCTION cranes quickly disappeared from the skyline of this affluent city near Seattle, office vacancy rates shot up as high as 28 percent and developers postponed once-ambitious projects when the dot-com boom went bust six years ago. Bellevue had become a city where no developer seemed to want to be. ''Everything was too good to be true, and then reality came through,'' said Kemper Freeman, the president and chief executive of Kemper Development, one of Bellevue's largest land owners and developers.

headline.main: The Cranes Are Back, And So Are the Tenants

abstract: Bellevue, Wash, is experiencing construction boom; dozen or so contruction cranes loom over works sites in city's downtown; some 2.2 million square feet of office space, some of it speculative, and more than 2,500 apartments and condominiums are under construction; Microsoft is expanding its offices in Bellevue; Eddie Bauer has chosen city for its new headquarters; Neiman Marcus is opening its first Pacific Northwest store in city; photos (L)
snippet: Bellevue, whose fortunes rose and fell with those of the technology industry, has been staging a comeback.

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled 53 years ago in Brown v. Board of Education that segregated education is inherently unequal, and it ordered the nation's schools to integrate. Yesterday, the court switched sides and told two cities that they cannot take modest steps to bring public school students of different races together. It was a sad day for the court and for the ideal of racial equality. Since 1954, the Supreme Court has been the nation's driving force for integration. Its orders required segregated buses and public buildings, parks and playgrounds to open up to all Americans. It wasn't always easy: governors, senators and angry mobs talked of massive resistance. But the court never wavered, and in many of the most important cases it spoke unanimously.

headline.main: Resegregation Now

abstract: Editorial says Supreme Court's radical new majority turned its back on half-century of previous rulings, telling public schools they cannot take modest steps to bring students of different races together; calls this sad day for court and for ideal of racial equality
snippet: Thursday was a sad day for the Supreme Court and for the ideal of racial equality.

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court's decision on school integration invalidated programs in Seattle and metropolitan Louisville, Ky. The Louisville schools, once segregated by law, operated under a federal court's desegregation order from 1975 until 2000, when the court found that the district had eliminated the vestiges of official segregation ''to the greatest extent possible.'' The next year, to keep the schools from resegregating, Jefferson County adopted the plan the Supreme Court struck down yesterday.

headline.main: How the Programs Linked to Race Worked in 2 Cities

abstract: Supreme Court decision on school integration invalidates programs in Seattle and Louisville, Ky; details noted on how programs operated; photos (M)
snippet: The Supreme Court’s decision on school integration invalidated programs in Seattle and metropolitan Louisville, Ky.

lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruling striking down voluntary programs to integrate schools in Seattle and Louisville, Ky., left hundreds of school districts struggling yesterday to assess whether they must change policies that use race as a factor in school assignments. Many lawyers said the 5-to-4 ruling would not end a half century of litigation over school desegregation but rather reignite it, as school districts turn to alternative methods for achieving diversity.

headline.main: Across U.S., a New Look at School Integration Efforts

abstract: Supreme Court decision invalidating voluntary programs to integrate schools in Seattle and Louisville, Ky, leaves hundreds of school districts struggling to assess whether they must change policies using race as factor in school assignments; many lawyers say decision will not end litigation over school desegregation but reignite it, as school districts turn to alternative methods for achieving diversity; photo (M)
snippet: The Supreme Court ruling striking down voluntary plans to integrate schools left hundreds of school districts struggling to assess whether they must change their policies.

lead_paragraph: With competing blocs of justices claiming the mantle of Brown v. Board of Education, a bitterly divided Supreme Court declared Thursday that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that take explicit account of a student's race. Voting 5 to 4, the court, in an opinion by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., invalidated programs in Seattle and metropolitan Louisville, Ky., that sought to maintain school-by-school diversity by limiting transfers on the basis of race or using race as a ''tiebreaker'' for admission to particular schools.

headline.main: Justices, Voting 5-4, Limit the Use of Race In Integration Plans

abstract: Supreme Court votes 5 to 4 that public school systems cannot seek to achieve or maintain integration through measures that consider student's race; both sides of bitterly divided court invoke Brown v Board of Education, arguing about meaning of racial discrimination; court, in opinion by Chief Justice John G Roberts, invalidates programs in Seattle and Louisville, Ky, that sought to maintain diversity by limiting school transfers on basis of race; programs had been upheld by lower federal courts and are similar to plans used across country; Justice Anthony M Kennedy agrees that two programs are unconstitutional, but does not join majority opinion that race cannot be factor in any circumstances; Justice Stephen G Breyer, in emotional dissenting opinion, disagrees with Kennedy's alternatives and says court is seriously mistaken; says decision will strip schools of tools they have used for years to prevent resegregation; photo (M)
snippet: Voting 5 to 4, the Supreme Court declared that public school systems cannot seek integration through measures that take explicit account of a student’s race.

lead_paragraph: SINCE 1954, liberal and conservative justices have disagreed about the central meaning of Brown v. Board of Education. Was the purpose of Brown to achieve a colorblind society or an integrated one? Last week, in its 5-to-4 decision declaring that public schools in Louisville and Seattle can't take explicit account of race to achieve integration, the Supreme Court came down firmly on the side of colorblindness. Despite some important qualifications by Justice Anthony Kennedy, at least four conservative justices made clear that they believe that nearly all racial classifications are unconstitutional.

headline.main: Can a Law Change A Society?

abstract: Some legal scholars question impact of Supreme Court decision declaring that public schools in Louisville and Seattle cannot take explicit account of race to achieve integration; are also questioning whether Brown v Board of Education was as singularly influential in transforming society as many have claimed since 1954 decision; argue that it was political commitment to integration in 1960s not Brown decision that led to meaningful integration; say that just as court could not bring about integration on its own in 1954, so it will not be able to mandate 'colorblindness' on its own today; some scholars say that school boards committed to affirmative action can find ways to circumvent ruling; decision may be limited by public division on how colorblind or integrated society should be; there are backlashes in both directions; photos (M)
snippet: Last week’s Supreme Court decision declared that public schools can’t take explicit account of race to achieve integration, but will a colorblindness mandate succeed?

lead_paragraph: Megan Peterson sat in the grass outside Ballard High School last week on the day before summer break started and offered an eyewitness account of how her school had changed. ''When we were freshman there were a lot more people of color than there are now,'' said Megan, who is 17 and will be a senior next fall. ''Every year it's less and less.''

headline.main: Seattle Schools Take Stock After Justices Issue Ruling

abstract: Seattle stopped using race as factor in assigning students to high school in 2002; district officials say that when Supreme Court struck down their use of race to determine where some students attended high school, known as integration tiebreaker, ruling was not defeat but affirmation that their heart was in right place, that rest was just matter of execution; while many school districts across country may be forced to revise or abandon race-based assignment plans, Seattle will feel little impact from ruling it helped prompt; photo (M)
snippet: While many school districts may be forced to abandon race-based assignment plans, Seattle will feel little impact from a ruling it helped prompt.

lead_paragraph: Amazon.com will begin selling high-definition independent films in the HD DVD format through its on-demand DVD printing service, the company said on Sunday. The company said it would waive processing fees for the first 1,000 films it accepts for production by its CustomFlix Labs subsidiary.

headline.main: Amazon.com to Sell More Films in HD DVD

abstract: Amazon.com will begin selling high-definition independent films in HD DVD format through its CustomFlix labs on-demand DVD printing service; HD DVD has been competing with rival Blu-ray format in effort to dominate market (S)
snippet: The company currently offers more than 300 HD DVD titles for sale on its site, and more than 400 that use the competing Blu-ray DVD format championed by Sony.

lead_paragraph: John Henry Browne, a criminal defense lawyer in Seattle, was steamed. A new Web site that rates lawyers the way Zagat rates restaurants, with numbers, had assigned him a low score. So Mr. Browne filed a class-action lawsuit last month.

headline.main: On Second Thought, Let's Just Rate all the Lawyers

abstract: Avvo.com is Web site that rates lawyers and allows consumers to search by specialty and location; many lawyers are incensed by ratings assigned them and Avvo does not disclose how it generates its ratings, though it says it relies on public records; Avvo faces suit filed by John Henry Browne, lawyer in Seattle dissatisfied with his rating; drawing (M)
snippet: John Henry Browne, a criminal defense lawyer in Seattle, was steamed. A new Web site that rates lawyers the way Zagat rates restaurants, with numbers, had assigned him a low score.

lead_paragraph: Experienced Supreme Court lawyers figured out long ago that they had to pitch their arguments to Justice Anthony M. Kennedy and Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who for years shared a place at the court's center. A new dynamic emerged in the court's last term, which ended last week with Justice Kennedy standing in the middle, all alone. Not only the lawyers, but also the justices themselves, are now in the business of courting him.

headline.main: Clues to the New Dynamic on the Supreme Court

abstract: Linda Greenhouse column on two Supreme Court's actions suggesting that Justice Anthony M Kennedy has emerged as sole swing justice to whom both lawyers and his colleagues must direct their arguments; they are 5-to-4 ruling invalidating voluntary school integration plans in Seattle and Louisville, Ky, and announcement that court will hear appeals by two groups of Guantanamo detainees challenging their lack of access to federal court; photo (M)
snippet: Not only lawyers, but also the justices themselves, are now in the business of courting Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who stands alone in the Supreme Court’s center.

lead_paragraph: When Justice Clarence Thomas provided a pivotal vote last month as the Supreme Court struck down school integration plans in Louisville, Ky., and Seattle, he suggested the concept of integration was inherently demeaning to black children because it implied they needed to mix with whites to achieve excellence. His comments, including his description of people who promote integration as faddish theorists, demonstrated anew his place as the most influential black voice criticizing the value of integration and affirmative action plans. But as Justice Thomas is also the most intensely scrutinized personality on the court, his comments inevitably raise questions about much his legal views are shaped by the difficulties of his own experience with race and education.

headline.main: Justice Secures His Place As a Critic of Integration

abstract: Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas' pivotal vote striking down school integration plans in Louisville, Ky, and Seattle, demonstrates again his place as most influential black voice criticizing value of integration and affirmative action plans; as most scrutinized personality on court, his comments raise questions about how much his legal views are shaped by difficulties of his own experience with race and education; his recent opinion on integration provides fresh material for rich debate about him among black scholars for whom he has been fascinating and vexing subject since his narrow court confirmation in 1991 (M)
snippet: Justice Clarence Thomas’s recent opinion on integration has provided fresh material for the rich debate about him among black scholars.

lead_paragraph: Step aside Steve Jobs. You, too, ''Ratatouille.'' In a nation where pocket-thin technology and Hollywood movies have hyped their way to consumer obsession, an unlikely rival for the public imagination is trying to restore a retro literalness, and largeness, to the art of the product rollout. On Sunday, before nearly 15,000 employees and worldwide customers in a hangar here in this Seattle suburb, with 25,000 others watching remotely from a football stadium downtown, Boeing unveiled the 787 Dreamliner, its new long-distance, fuel-efficient jet, which already has $110 billion worth of orders for 677 planes.

headline.main: Amid Fanfare, Boeing Unveils New Long-Distance Jet

abstract: Boeing unveils 787 Dreamliner, its new long-distance, fuel-efficient jet, before nearly 15,000 employees and worldiwde customers in hangar in Everett, Washington; 25,000 others watch remotely from nearby football stadium; jet already has $110 billion worth of orders for 677 planes; photos (M)
snippet: The arrival of the 787 Dreamliner highlights what a striking counterpoint Western Washington has been in a country where manufacturing jobs have long been in decline.

lead_paragraph: BANNED in Pittsburgh? Controversy over a new advertising campaign by Trojan, the condom maker, has trickled down to the local level, with television stations in Pittsburgh roundly refusing to show it, and stations in Seattle giving it the green light.

headline.main: With Condoms In Particular, Local Stations Can Say No

abstract: Advertisement for Trojan condoms is rejected by some television networks and local stations while being accepted by others; Jim Daniels, vice president for marketing at Trojan, says it is hypocritical and irresponsible for networks to run sexually explicit programming, but to reject ads that promote prevention of pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases; photo (M)
snippet: Controversy over a new advertising campaign by Trojan, the condom maker, has trickled down to the local level.

lead_paragraph: The search for the self-described pedophile in the large-brimmed black hat commences nearly every day here, with findings posted on chat rooms frequented by mothers. He was spotted at a fair in Santa Clarita. He recently emerged from the Social Security office on Olympic Boulevard. He tapped away on a computer at the library in Mar Vista. Warnings have gone out. Signs have been posted.

headline.main: Parents' Ire Grows at Pedophile's Unabashed Blog

abstract: Jack McClellan, self-described pedophile, has had Web sites in Seattle and Los Angeles detailing how and where he likes to troll for children; police can do nothing because he has no record and appears to be doing nothing illegal, but his mere presence in Los Angeles--coupled with McClellan's commitment to exhibitionistic blogging about his thoughts on little girls--has set parents on edge; some mothers plan to push lawmakers in Sacramento to legislate McClellan out of business; they want to make it illegal to post images of children of any type on Web sites with sexual content or themes; McClellan photo (M)
snippet: The Los Angeles police say they have no legal recourse against a man who writes about how he trolls for children.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Alain Delaquérière contributed reporting from New York

lead_paragraph: SNOHOMISH, Wash. THE issue, a scant four decades ago, was simple.

headline.main: A Simple Thirst, a Great Cab

abstract: Development of Washington State wine industry in 1970's, which was spearheaded by Quilceda Creek label, discussed; Alex Golitzin, who founded Quilceda Creek Vintners, says that he was inspired to make wine because at that time wine was not readily available in region; photo (M)
snippet: An engineer in search of decent wine in Seattle four decades ago decides to make his own. The result is a trim, handsome winery housing one of America’s greatest producers of cabernet sauvignon.

lead_paragraph: The Seattle office market has made a spectacular recovery in the last few years. As a result many real estate investors want to park their money there. No one knows that better than Alfred Clise. His real estate investment company, Clise Properties, is selling a 13-acre parcel in downtown Seattle that his family cobbled together over 80 years. The land, amounting to nearly seven blocks, now mainly occupied by parking lots and low-rise office buildings, has no asking price.

headline.main: Investors Lining Up for Pieces of Seattle's Comeback

abstract: Seattle real estate market has experienced spectacular recovery in last few years as many investors look to city; Clise Properties is prepared to sell 13-acre parcel in downtown Seattle to buyer who has singular, grand vision for space; analysts see market as one of strongest in country; photos (M)
snippet: The Seattle office market has made a spectacular recovery in the last few years, and as a result, many real estate investors want to park their money there.

lead_paragraph: Chris Benz may be originally from Seattle, but don't expect his customers to rock out in lumberjack flannels or defaced denim. ''I like the ease and recklessness of grunge, but I'm not into holes,'' says the 24-year-old Parsons graduate (top), who was awarded a Council of Fashion Designers of America scholarship before interning for Marc Jacobs and working for J. Crew. His debut collection (go to www.chris-benz.com) was inspired by old-school glamour: the jazz-era shirtdresses, mohair jackets, mink jockey caps and twill jodhpurs had a flapper-meets-slacker vibe that never seemed stagey. ''I'll do slouchy pants with low belt loops and a wallet chain for a tomboy look,'' he says. ''But I'm just as likely to put a chiffon flower on a blouse that Jordan Baker might have worn in 'The Great Gatsby.' '' He says his historical eclectism comes from a childhood spent rummaging through his grandmother's attic. Cedar chips and old clothes? Just don't call it grunge.

headline.main: History Boy

snippet: Chris Benz may be originally from Seattle, but don’t expect his customers to rock out in lumberjack flannels or defaced denim.

lead_paragraph: Earlier this summer a concerned crew member of a Washington State ferry boat snapped pictures of two men who had raised suspicions on several ferry rides by asking questions about structural details and entering areas of the boats that are off limits. Now, after the Federal Bureau of Investigation released two photographs of the men to the public with the goal of identifying them, a debate has erupted over alleged racial profiling, one ferry was shut down briefly this week and the men, while suddenly familiar faces, remain unidentified.

headline.main: Debate Swirls Around 2 Men on a Ferry

abstract: Debate has erupted over alleged profiling after FBI releases photographs of two men who aroused suspicion of crew member of Washington State ferry by asking questions about structural details and entering off-limits areas on several rides; Muslim groups say men could be perceived as Middle Eastern; men remain unidentified and no threats to ferry system have been made; photo (M)
snippet: A federal effort to identify two men whose behavior raised suspicion in Washington State has sparked a debate over alleged racial profiling.

lead_paragraph: Of all people, Jeff Boyd should have known better. He is president of a company, Luggage Free, that is one of several luggage delivery services founded in the wake of 9/11 when antiterrorism measures required that air travelers' luggage be left unlocked, and thefts rose as a result. But last February, Mr. Boyd and his girlfriend, Lindsey Wieber, did not use the delivery service and instead checked their luggage for a flight from New York to Park City, Utah, where they planned to go skiing. When their flight was canceled, they took another. Their luggage showed up the next day, with half their things missing.

headline.main: No Suitcase Is Safe

abstract: Transportation Security Administration report on passenger claims for theft, loss or damage to personal items from luggage in 2004 ranked Los Angeles International Airport at top, with 1,458 claims, followed by O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, with 963 claims; Seattle-Tacoma International Airport came in third, with 904 claims; number of claims is fraction of real number of thefts; many people do not report their loss because they are frustrated with paperwork; they do not have time to track down security officer as they go to next flight; they do not have insurance or they do not know they have been robbed until they get home and find something missing from their checked luggage; some airports in Latin America and Africa are known for high rates of theft, with airport security personnel and even government officials sometimes working with thieves; experts say airports anywhere can be targets of thieves; photo (M)
snippet: Some airports in Latin America and Africa are known for high rates of theft, but experts say airport baggage thieves prosper in the U.S. as well.

lead_paragraph: New York is a major player in many realms, but when it comes to high technology, it is often dismissed as minor league. An article in Popular Science magazine in 2005, for example, rated New York 39th among high-tech cities, behind Milwaukee (31st). Minneapolis/St. Paul topped the list. But a new report says that New York actually has more high-tech workers than meccas like Silicon Valley and Seattle, and that it is just a matter knowing where to look for them.

headline.main: Peeking Into Cubicles to Find A Wealth of Tech Workers

abstract: Nonprofit Industrial and Technology Assistance Corporation study finds that New York City has more high-tech workers than meccas like Silicon Valley and Seattle, Wash; says many high-tech workers are 'embedded' in other sectors and were thus previously overlooked in past tallies (M)
snippet: New York is a major player in many realms, but when it comes to high technology, it is often dismissed as minor league. An article in Popular Science magazine in 2005, for example, rated New York 39th among high-tech cities, behind Milwaukee (31st)....

lead_paragraph: FULL PLANES The 10 largest domestic carriers posted average load factors of about 85 percent in August. Load factor is the percentage of available seats occupied by paying passengers. Load factors exceeding 80 percent indicate that all seats were occupied on most flights. The highest load factor in August was reported by Northwest Airlines, at 88.5 percent. GREEN LIGHT FOR AIR TAXIS DayJet, the fledgling air-taxi service that will use a fleet of new Eclipse 500 very light jets, got Federal Aviation Administration authorization to begin regular service. The carrier, which plans to begin operations flying between cities in Florida, has not announced a starting date but said it would begin taking bookings within weeks. The start was delayed by a technological snag, now resolved, that prevented the little jets from being cleared for instrument flying.

headline.main: Memo Pad

abstract: Memo Pad column; 10 largest domestic carriers posted average load factors of about 85 percent in August; highest load factor was reported by Northwest Airlines, at 88.5 percent; DayJet, fledgling air-taxi service that use fleet of new Eclipse 500 very light jets, gets Federal Aviation Administration approval to begin regular service; carrier, which plans to begin operations flying between cities in Florida, has not announced starting date; Horizon Air is trying to lure business travelers who drive on some short routes rather than deal with flight delays and congested airports; it has new ad campaign and fare promotion directed at those who drive 200 miles on Interstate 5 between Seattle and Portland, Ore; is promoting walk-up fare of $99 each way on Seattle-Portland shuttle; starting Oct 1, it will cost 2 pounds ($4.06) to check bag on European discount carrier easyJet; currently, first checked bag is free on easyJet, and additional checked bags cost 5 pounds ($10.15); all-business-class airline MaxJet begins four-times-a-week service between Los Angeles International and London Stansted with round-trip fares at $1,398 plus tax; China Southern Airlines selects Panasonic Avionics to supply eX2 in-flight digital entertainment and communications systems on 10 Boeing 787 Dreamliners it has ordered; United Airlines plans to replace old video recorder systems with digital in-flight entertainment systems on certain planes; India's Shangri-La Hotels and Resorts plans to open four new hotels in 2009, one in Mumbai and three others in Bangalore (M)
snippet: FULL PLANES The 10 largest domestic carriers posted average load factors of about 85 percent in August. Load factor is the percentage of available seats occupied by paying passengers. Load factors exceeding 80 percent indicate that all seats were...

lead_paragraph: No one had heard from Tanya Rider for more than a week. Her husband, having already opened up their bank and phone accounts to investigators, was just sitting down to take a polygraph test to prove that he had not harmed her. Then they found her, alive.

headline.main: Missing Woman Found Alive In Wrecked Car After 8 Days

abstract: Rescuers find Tanya Rider eight days after her car ran off road and plunged down ravine near Seattle suburb; she is in critical but stable condition; photo (M)
snippet: Tanya Rider, who had been missing for more than a week, was found 20 feet down a roadside ravine in a Seattle suburb after the signal from her cellphone led investigators to her.

lead_paragraph: Helen Elaine Freeman, a conservationist who fell in love with two snow leopards when she was a volunteer at a zoo and eventually founded a leading advocacy organization working to preserve them, died on Sept. 20 in Bellevue, Wash. She was 75. The cause was lung disease, according to the Snow Leopard Trust, which she founded in 1981.

headline.main: Helen E. Freeman, 75; Worked to Protect Snow Leopards

abstract: Helen Elaine Freeman, conservationist and founder of leading advocacy organization working to preserve snow leopards, dies at age 75 (M)
snippet: Helen Elaine Freeman was a conservationist who fell in love with two snow leopards when she was a volunteer at a zoo and eventually founded a leading advocacy organization working to preserve them.

lead_paragraph: The former Blackwater USA employee who is the sole suspect in the killing last Christmas Eve of a bodyguard for an Iraqi vice president is a 27-year-old former Army paratrooper from Montana who now lives in Seattle, where he spends much of his time renovating his small home. The former employee, Andrew J. Moonen, is identified in numerous government and company documents and is known to scores of Blackwater and government officials, but Congress, the State Department and the company have been keeping his identity confidential.

headline.main: Ex-Paratrooper Is Suspect In Drunken Killing of Iraqi

abstract: Andrew J Moonen, former Blackwater USA employee who is sole suspect in killing of bodyguard for Iraqi Vice Pres Adel Abdul Mahdi after drunken confrontation in December 2006, declines to discuss episode, but says he is uneasy about recent news about Blackwater in Iraq; Blackwater founder Erik D Prince says company fined Moonen thousands of dollars and shipped him home to Seattle for violating policy; photo (M)
snippet: A former Blackwater USA employee is under investigation in the killing last year of a bodyguard for an Iraqi official.

byline.original: By JOHN M. BRODER; J. Michael Kennedy contributed reporting from Seattle, Jim Robbins from Kalispell, Mont., and Barclay Walsh from Washington

lead_paragraph: Out here next to Steamboat Slough and the lumber mill, piles of garbage from Seattle are lined up in neat rows and blanketed with a fabric similar to that used in high-end Gore-Tex clothing. What goes in as yard waste and food scraps will emerge two months later as a mountain of loamy compost sold by the bag at garden centers throughout the Pacific Northwest by Cedar Grove Composting. In the process, the waste is ground up, piled up, aerated, dried and sifted. The space-age fabric covering the piles allows air to enter but keeps pungent odors from wafting over the countryside.

headline.main: Seattle's Recycling Success Is Being Measured in Scraps

abstract: Seattle recycles 44 percent of its trash, much of it turned into compost by Cedar Grove Composting in Everett, Wash; city waste management officials say goal is to reach 60 percent by 2012 and 72 percent by 2025; in many other parts of country recycling is in doldrums despite sounding of environmental alarms; photos (M)
snippet: Seattle now recycles 44 percent of its trash, compared with the national average of around 30 percent, which makes it a major player in big city waste recovery.

lead_paragraph: Velocity Art and Design started in 1999 as a Web-only venture in the basement of John and Lara Tusher's house in Seattle while he was an elementary school teacher and she was a nurse. They offered high-design brands like Vitra and Pure Design, and were among the first to sell Jonathan Adler online. They developed enough of a following to open their first bricks-and-mortar store a year later, and this month they moved to a 3,000-square-foot space in the rapidly gentrifying South Lake Union neighborhood. IBRIDE TRAYS, $59

headline.main: Velocity Art and Design

abstract: Home furnishings that Velocity Art and Design shop in Seattle hopes will be best sellers next season are discussed; photos (S)

lead_paragraph: The sun was shining for a change, which was good news for Richard Thompson, known throughout these parts as Solar Richard. ''Pennies from heaven,'' Mr. Thompson said as his electric meter spun round -- in reverse.

headline.main: For a Devotee of Solar Energy, a Shot at Earning Respect

abstract: New mile-long Tacoma Narrows Bridge, at urging of solar energy expert Richard Thompson, is on its way to being lighted with solar power; Washington State has contributed $1.5 million toward project; Thompson photo (M)
snippet: Richard Thompson, who began powering his home with solar power in 2001, has found that power is the easy part. Generating interest takes work.

lead_paragraph: The mayor of Fayetteville, Ark., gushed through a slide show about how his city was in the midst of great change. Bleak roads and bland shopping strips were being redrawn to a more human scale. Downtown condominiums were going for a million dollars. Streets once silent at night now bustled. Besides being great for the local economy, the mayor, Dan Coody, told his counterparts from other cities gathered here, the redevelopment is also helping Fayetteville go green.

headline.main: Mayors, Looking to Cities' Future, Are Told It Must Be Colored Green

abstract: About 100 mayors attend two-day Climate Protection Summit in Seattle convened by US Conference of Mayors; conference presents two main themes: federal government must do more than Bush administration has done to fight global warming, and in meantime, cities must take up slack; photo (M)
snippet: A summit convened by the U.S. Conference of Mayors presented two main themes: the federal government must do more to fight global warming; and in the meantime, cities must take up the slack.

lead_paragraph: THE meal was open to just 40 people. They had to sign up before they could learn the address, that of a vacant bank in this city's industrial-chic Georgetown neighborhood.

headline.main: Outrageous? He's Heard That Before

abstract: Article on underground restaurateur Michael Hebberoy, who, after disappearing in April 2006 and leaving behind ruined restaurant empire, welter of debt and angry creditors and business partners, has resurfaced in Seattle as host of One Pot, series of theme dinners in clandestine locations; recalls family suppers of past, held at changing series of secret locations, that made Hebberoy famous; photos (M)
snippet: After leaving behind a wife, a ruined restaurant empire and a welter of debt, an underground restaurateur returns.

multimedia.caption: Clandestine Dining
multimedia.credit: Scenes from "One Pot," an underground restaurant series run by Michael Hebberoy in Seattle.

lead_paragraph: An article in the Dining section yesterday about Michael Hebberoy, who runs public dinners in clandestine locations around Seattle and was a popular restaurateur in Portland, Ore., before his businesses went bankrupt last year, referred incorrectly to the decision by The Oregonian to name Mr. Hebberoy's restaurant Clarklewis the city's restaurant of the year in 2004. The Oregonian gave the restaurant top honors three months after it opened; the newspaper did not do so ''before it even opened.''

abstract: Correction of article in Nov 7 Dining section about Michael Hebberoy and clandestine dinners he runs around Seattle

lead_paragraph: The Moocher introduced them years ago down by the ferry terminal, near that ''No Loitering'' sign scratched up to read ''Know Loitering.'' It was Ed, meet Daryl, Daryl, Ed, between sips and slugs of bottom-shelf whiskey and high-octane beer.

headline.main: On the Bottle, Off the Streets, Halfway There

abstract: Dan Barry This Land column on visit to Seattle to profile Vietnam vets Ed Myers and Daryl Jordan, who have found spots in residence for homeless chronic alcoholics that allows drinking; says goal of Downtown Emergency Service Center is to provide homes and meals, gain trust and encourage residents to partake of available services; map; photos (M)
snippet: A residence for homeless alcoholics that allows drinking has inspired angry complaints that it uses public money to enable, even reward, chronic inebriates.

byline.original: By DAN BARRY; Online: Voices from Seattle's 1811 Eastlake Project. www.nytimes.com/danbarry

lead_paragraph: A changing of the guard was predicted in the N.F.C. West. But San Francisco and Arizona have not put up much of a fight, even though Seattle, the three-time defending champion, has left the door wide open. With Shaun Alexander injured and ineffective, Seahawks Coach Mike Holmgren has renewed focus on the passing game, which is ranked 10th in the league. The 49ers, losers of six in a row, wish they had only one facet of their 32nd-ranked offense to be concerned about. The Seahawks, who won in San Francisco in Week 4, are hungry for payback after a season sweep by the 49ers last year. San Francisco Coach Mike Nolan's father, Dick Nolan, a former Giants player and 49ers coach, died yesterday, but Mike Nolan is expected to be with his team tonight. NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

headline.main: Today's Matchup

snippet: A changing of the guard was predicted in the N.F.C. West. But San Francisco and Arizona have not put up much of a fight, even though Seattle, the three-time defending champion, has left the door wide open. With Shaun Alexander injured and...

lead_paragraph: The female condom has never caught on in the United States. But in the third world, where it was introduced in the late 1990s, public health workers hoped it would overthrow the politics of the bedroom, empower women and stop the AIDS epidemic in its tracks. It did not. Female condoms never really caught on there, either.

headline.main: Redesigning A Condom So Women Will Use It

abstract: Article on redesign of female condom, which has been undertaken by PATH, nonprofit group based in Seattle, Wash; new design, however, does not overcome glaring drawback that doomed first one--it cannot be used secretly; drawings (M)
snippet: A female version of AIDS protection was never popular, but now scientists are trying again.

lead_paragraph: For many American Indian tribes, a watershed moment occurs when they open a casino, which provides a stream of steady income. For the Tulalip tribes, a group of several tribes on this reservation about 35 miles north of Seattle, the casino was also a springboard for new real estate ventures -- which in turn are helping to transform a rural area into one of Washington state's fastest-growing suburbs. The economic engine is Quil Ceda Village, a commercial area within the reservation, where the tribes built a 225,000-square-foot casino in 2003.

headline.main: Near Seattle, Tribal Casinos Lead to Even Bigger Bets

abstract: Casino built on Tulalip Indian Reservation in Washington State in 2003 was springboard for Quil Ceda Village, commercial area within reservation; village also has Home Depot, Wal-Mart and more than dozen other stores, banks and restaurants; tribes added open-air mall in 2005; hospitality and retail properties are beginning; about 1,000 of 2,000 acres that tribes have set aside for Quil Ceda have yet to be developed; tribes are considering erecting industrial buildings; tribes are currently working on $130 million 12-story Tulalip Hotel, which is to open next July; photos (L)
snippet: A group of several American Indian tribes who live about 35 miles north of Seattle are helping to transform a rural area into one of Washington state’s fastest-growing suburbs.

lead_paragraph: Lakewood Ranch, Fla. WHAT: A three-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath house built in 2004 on a golf course in Lakewood Ranch Country Club.

headline.main: What You Get for...$900,000

snippet: A three-bedroom house in Lakewood Ranch, Fla., a four-bedroom house in Whitefish, Mont., and a waterfront apartment in West Seattle, Wash.

multimedia.credit: Properties on the market in Florida, Montana and Washington.

lead_paragraph: Look for two more items on the sale rack after Thanksgiving: the Chinook and the Snohomish, last seen ferrying people across Puget Sound. The big boats can be yours for $4.5 million each. As is. Exclusively at eBay. ''The state decided to get out of the passenger-only ferry business,'' said Traci Brewer-Rogstad, director of operations for Washington State Ferries.

headline.main: For Sale From Puget Sound: 2 Fixer-Upper Ferries

abstract: Washington State Ferries is selling passenger ferries Snohomish and Chinook for $4.5 million each four years after budget cuts, controversy and declining ridership ended service on so-called foot-service route between Seattle and Bremerton; state plans to focus its ferry system on core operations with vehicle ferries; photo (M)
snippet: Washington State is selling passenger-only boats and focusing its ferry system on its core operations, larger boats that carry vehicles as well as people.

lead_paragraph: For Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, happy hour in the Emerald City means more than just half-price drinks.

headline.main: Frugal Seattle

snippet: For Matt Gross, the Frugal Traveler, happy hour in the Emerald City means more than just half-price drinks.

lead_paragraph: THE dining room at Cascadia -- one of Seattle's top restaurants, with a cutting-edge chef, luminous décor and a cellar lauded by Wine Spectator -- was empty. No one sat on the green banquettes, eating Alaskan king crab with white-truffle gnocchi under the coppery mahogany paneling, and empty wineglasses sparkled on white tablecloths. Only an occasional wandering waiter disturbed this stillness. Across a frosted-glass divider, however, Cascadia's bar growled with energy. Every stool was taken on this Friday night, and upscale Seattleites mobbed the lounge and the sidewalk tables, where the setting sun warmed their faces and melted the ice in their cocktails. Of course no one was at dinner -- this was happy hour.

headline.main: Sampling the Best Of the Northwest

abstract: Matt Gross travel article on weekend visit to Seattle, Washington, on budget of $500; photos (L)
snippet: To the Frugal Traveler, no phrase is more inspiring than “happy hour.” In Seattle, those 60 minutes of joy have been elevated into evenings not only of cheap drinks but also of discount gourmet snacks at the classiest restaurants.

multimedia.caption: Video: Frugal Seattle
multimedia.credit: In the Emerald City, happy hour means more than just half-price drinks: it means heavily discounted gourmet snacks from the best restaurants in town.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: In the Emerald City, happy hour means more than just half-price drinks: it means heavily discounted gourmet snacks from the best restaurants in town.

lead_paragraph: The decline in home prices accelerated and spread to more regions of the country in October, according to data released Wednesday. Prices fell 6.1 percent from October 2006 in 20 large metropolitan areas, according to Standard & Poor's/Case-Shiller indexes, compared with a 4.9 percent decline in September. On a monthly basis, prices fell 1.4 percent in October, the fastest they have declined in at least the last seven years.

headline.main: Home Prices Fell Faster In October

abstract: Standard & Poor's/Case-Shiller indexes show home prices fell 6.1 percent in October from October 2006 in 20 large metropolitan areas, compared with 4.9 percent in September; quickening pace of decline could hurt broader economy by leading to more foreclosures as homeowners have difficulty refinancing mortgages and by sapping consumer spending as Americans feell less wealthy; prices are dropping fastest in Midwest, California, Florida and Southwest; Northwest Multiple Listing Services says pending sales of single-family homes and condos in Seattle area fell by one third in September from same month last year; graph (L)
snippet: The decline in home prices accelerated and spread to more regions of the country in October, according to new data.

lead_paragraph: Six people were found shot to death at a home in a rural part of King County on Wednesday, and investigators arrested two people they said were responsible for the killings, law enforcement officials said. The victims included two children. ''We still don't have a motive as such, but the suspects are known to the victims,'' said John Urquhart, a spokesman for the King County Sheriff's Office.

headline.main: 6 in Family Are Found Slain in Home Outside Seattle

abstract: Police find six members of family, including two children, shot to death in rural area home outside Seattle; decline to identify victims; arrest property owner's daughter Michele Anderson and boyfriend Joseph McEnroe as suspects; photo (M)
snippet: Six people were found shot to death at a rural home and investigators arrested two people they said were responsible for the killings.

lead_paragraph: It is considered one of the great unsolved mysteries of American crime: how a seemingly quiet man in his mid-40s hijacked an airliner somewhere between Seattle and Reno in November 1971, then parachuted in his loafers and trench coat, making off with $200,000 in cash. Who was he? Did he survive? After all these years, federal authorities say they still do not know, and the case lingers and vexes and fascinates as the only unsolved airplane hijacking in United States history. ''It's a mystery, frankly,'' agency officials said in a December news release issued periodically to update old cases.

headline.main: F.B.I. Brings a Fresh Set of Eyes to a '71 Plane Hijacking Mystery

abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation for first time is providing pictures and information related to still unsolved 1971 D B Cooper airliner hijacking case on its Web site; federal agent Larry Carr is taking new look at crime, approaching it as if he were investigating bank robbery; Cooper, if he is still alive, would be about 85 years old; drawings; photos (M)
snippet: How did a man hijack an airliner in November 1971, then parachute in his loafers and trench coat and make off with $200,000?

lead_paragraph: They met near the Seahawks logo at midfield. Tim Ruskell, the general manager and architect of the revamped defense, extended a hand. Matt Hasselbeck, the quarterback and offensive engineer, shook it. They were surrounded by a stadium full of screaming fans wearing green stocking caps, next to an owner, the billionaire Paul Allen, who walked along the front row and slapped every outstretched hand.

headline.main: In Game of Swings, Final One Tilts to Seahawks

abstract: Seattle Seahawks defeat Washington Redskins, 35-14, in NFC wild-card game; photo (M)
snippet: Seahawks safety Jordan Babineaux returned a 57-yard interception for a touchdown with 27 seconds left, to give the Seahawks their final points in a 35-14 victory.

lead_paragraph: Amazon.com, the world's largest online retailer, will soon finally have one place to call home. The company is moving all of its administrative employees, who are now scattered in offices around Seattle, to a single location in the city. It will be the first time all of these employees are together since the founding of Amazon more than a decade ago.

headline.main: Amazon Consolidates in Growing Area of Seattle

abstract: Amazon.com, world's largest online retailer, is moving all of its administrative employees, who are now scattered in offices around Seattle, to 11 buildings in South Lake Union, lakefront neighborhood about mile north of downtown; it will be first time all of these employees are together since founding of company more than decade ago; construction begins in January, and 4,000 employees are expected to start moving in little over two years to campus that will eventually occupy six blocks; photos (L)
snippet: Amazon.com, the world’s largest online retailer, will soon finally have one place to call home.

lead_paragraph: ALL 213 students at New Lebanon Elementary, a small neighborhood school in the Byram section of Greenwich, walk or are driven to school. But soon, children from other parts of town will take buses to join them. To adhere to a state statute that says schools must be racially balanced, New Lebanon is becoming a magnet school.

headline.main: For Magnet School, Protests and Hurdles

abstract: Article on challenges that New Lebanon Elementary in Greenwich, Conn, faces as it switches to magnet school in order to comply with state statute mandating racial balance; many residents oppose plan and some have asked local Board of Education to hold off until Attorney General Richard Blumenthal weighs in on legality of state statute in light of Supreme Court decisions in Louisville, Ky, and Seattle, Wash; photos (M)
snippet: Two Supreme Court decisions may complicate a plan to create a new magnet school in Greenwich designed to comply with the state’s racial imbalance law.

lead_paragraph: Boeing's great success in selling its 787 Dreamliner -- it has 817 of the fuel-efficient planes on order, valued at more than $100 billion -- is turning to a period of frustration. As soon as Wednesday, the company, based here, is expected to announce another delay in the plane's production, which could push delivery into 2009. The original delivery date had been May.

headline.main: Boeing Is Expected to Disclose Further Delays in the Production of the 787

abstract: Boeing is expected to announce another delay in production of its 787 Dreamliner; delay could push delivery into 2009; original delivery date was May 2008; 817 of planes valued at more than $100 billion are on order (M)
snippet: The company is expected to announce another delay in production of its popular 787 Dreamliner, which could frustrate some international airlines’ expansion plans.

lead_paragraph: DRINK coffee. Put on another layer of dry clothes. Repeat. This is the formula to warm inside and out. Then attack a Seattle winter day undaunted, ignoring downpours like the locals, who act as if the epidermis were made of Gore-Tex. The first stop is a coffee shop, haunt or outdoor stand. Which one is best is a matter of grave dispute in a city where caffeine rivals precipitation in ubiquity.

headline.main: Seattle

abstract: Matt Richtel article on things to do on wintry day in Seattle; photo (M)
snippet: Drink coffee. Put on another layer of dry clothes. Repeat. This is the formula to warm inside and out in this city.

multimedia.caption: 5 Big Cities, 1 Winter Day
multimedia.credit: The perfect urban winter day in Chicago, Atlanta, Boston, Washington and Seattle.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The perfect urban winter day in Chicago, Atlanta, Boston, Washington and Seattle.

lead_paragraph: The SuperSonics' losing streak reached 11 games last Monday with a loss to the Rockets in Houston, then mechanical problems forced the team plane to land temporarily in Oklahoma City. The Sonics spent two hours playing cards, watching tape and cracking jokes while they waited for another plane to come from California. If only briefly, everything hanging over this strange season -- the longest single-season losing streak in team history, the dispute with the city of Seattle, the threat of relocation -- faded into the background.

headline.main: Devalued Sonics Seek New Arena Or a New City To Call Home

abstract: Seattle SuperSonics look to revitalize team, and could make move to Oklahoma City (Okla), where team's owners are based; photos (M)
snippet: This season, the SuperSonics have dealt with the longest single-season losing streak in team history, a dispute with the city of Seattle and the threat of relocation to Oklahoma City.

lead_paragraph: Gray and green may be the colors most associated with this forward-focused city, but it has a history in other tones, too. Chinese immigrants helped build railroads, only to be driven out later. Japanese residents were forced into internment camps during World War II. Blacks surged into the city after the war for work. Hispanics are the fastest-growing group. This year, two new museums and a new traditional gate marking the city's Chinatown will be completed, formally acknowledging the role minority groups have played in shaping Seattle and the region -- even as those roles are changing. The new touchstones will meet dueling misperceptions: that the city has had a bland racial past and that tolerance and unity are among the local natural resources.

headline.main: Seattle Takes Steps to Recognize Minorities' Role in Shaping Region

snippet: Two new museums and a new traditional gate marking the city’s Chinatown will be completed this year, acknowledging the role minority groups have played in shaping Seattle and the region.

lead_paragraph: Patty Stonesifer, who helped start the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation in an office over a pizza parlor seven years ago and has overseen its growth it into the world's largest philanthropic institution, said in an interview on Wednesday that she would step down by the end of the year. Her decision marks a major turning point for the foundation, which has operated largely as a family foundation overseen by Ms. Stonesifer, a friend and confidante of Bill Gates, a co-founder of Microsoft.

headline.main: Gates Foundation Head To Leave Longtime Post

abstract: Interview with Patty Stonesifer, who is stepping down after seven years as chief executive of Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation; photo (M)
snippet: Patty Stonesifer, who helped start and develop the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, is stepping down, marking a major turning point for the philanthropic foundation.

lead_paragraph: Many communities dream of becoming the next Silicon Valley. This one is actually doing it.

headline.main: Seattle Taps Its Inner Silicon Valley

abstract: Fremont District of Seattle, Wash, is becoming next Silicon Valley; Google recently opened research lab there, its second in Microsoft's backyard; technology start-ups are sprouting up amid quirky neighborhood landmarks; more young companies are moving in downtown while others are spreading into surrounding suburbs; University of Washington is fostering entrepreneurial climate in Seattle way Stanford University does in Silicon Valley; another advantage is tech-savvy talent at Seattle-based Amazon and nearby Microsoft; influx of entrepreneurs and of venture capitals to bankroll them is slowing reshaping city and regional economy; venture capital investment has more than tripled during last 12 months, to about $1 billion annually; photo of Jenny Lam, Hillel Cooperman and Walter Smith of software company Jackson Fish Market (L)
snippet: Many communities dream of becoming the next Silicon Valley. But Seattle is actually doing it.

lead_paragraph: Loggers, bloggers, farmers and philanthropists. Political relevance does not come around often for the distinctive mix of constituencies that keeps things lively here in the other Washington. So this Saturday, when presidential caucuses will be held statewide, people plan to make the most of it. Turnout is expected to be high, regardless of the usual February forecast for much of the state: rain. About 100,000 people participated in the caucuses in 2004. Twice that many could show up this time, according to some of the bolder predictions, and political experts note particular passion among Democrats over issues including the war in Iraq, health care and the environment.

headline.main: Politics in Washington State Are Lively Though Puzzling

abstract: Turnout in Washington state presidential caucuses is expected to be high; as many as 200,000 people are expected to weigh in; there is particular passion among Democrats over issues; mystery is which groups of voters will show up in biggest numbers, and whether they can figure out puzzling rules; photos (M)
snippet: Turnout in Washington is expected to be high, but the mystery is which groups of voters will show up in the biggest numbers  and whether they can figure out the rules.

lead_paragraph: As the Bush administration and Congress consider proposals to ease the home foreclosure crisis, local governments across the country have been lending money to imperiled homeowners and confronting some opposition. Some of these municipal and state efforts have met resistance from people who consider the assistance undeserved and adamantly oppose anything that resembles a taxpayer bailout.

headline.main: Foreclosure Aid Rising Locally, As Is Dissent

abstract: Local governments nationwide have been lending money to imperiled homeowners, causing opposition among people who consider assistance undeserved; Seattle began modest program in January, offering loans of up to $5,000 to help few dozen homeowners avoid losing their homes; aside from residents hoping to apply, few people are enthusiastic about program; local programs pit what some government officials say are practical economic solutions for common good against individual ideals of fairness and personal responsibility; negative reactions have not stopped assistance efforts but they have put some local officials on defensive and forced them to try to sell programs to general public; photo (M)
snippet: Efforts to help imperiled homeowners have met resistance from people who consider the assistance undeserved.

lead_paragraph: 1411 North 45th Street, Seattle; (206) 633-0801; tilthrestaurant.com. Did I let in a draft? Should I take off my shoes?

headline.main: 9. Tilth

snippet: Tilth, whose name refers to tilled earth, boasts an organic certification  from the exacting Oregon Tilth association.

lead_paragraph: Five luxury homes in a subdivision marketed as ''built green'' near here were destroyed or severely damaged by fire early Monday, and evidence at the scene suggested the fires might have been started by radical environmentalists who viewed the homes as violating rather than complementing the wooded wetlands in which they were built. ''Built green?'' read letters spray-painted onto a bedsheet found hanging on a fence at the site, about 25 miles northeast of Seattle. ''Nope Black!

headline.main: Ecoterrorism Suspected in House Fires in Seattle Suburb

abstract: Five luxury homes marketed as 'built green,' but criticized by some as ruining suburban Seattle wetlands, are severely damaged by fire; evidence suggests that fires might have been started by Earth Liberation Front, loosely organized group that has been linked to acts of ecoterrorism across Northwest and elsewhere for two decades; photos (M)
snippet: Five luxury homes in a subdivision marketed as “built green” were destroyed or severely damaged by fire. The initials of a group linked to acts of ecoterrorism were found at the scene.

lead_paragraph: TEN years ago, Nancy Pearl started a program for public libraries here that she hoped would get adults excited about literature. It was called, ''If All of Seattle Read the Same Book.'' Free copies of ''The Sweet Hereafter,'' a novel about a tragic school bus accident, were distributed to individuals and book clubs. Posters encouraged people to read the book and discuss it at library-sponsored events.

headline.main: Book Lovers Ask, What's Seattle's Secret?

snippet: Though the big publishing houses are still in New York, the Seattle area is home to Amazon, Starbucks and Costco, companies that increasingly influence what America reads.

lead_paragraph: The cashier's chorus has long fallen on deaf ears among the sustainability set here. Paper or plastic? ''Neither'' is of course the greenest answer. Soon, however, ''neither'' may be the cheapest answer, too.

headline.main: For Seattle Shoppers, Paper or Plastic Could Come with a 'Green Fee'

abstract: Mayor Greg Nickels wants Seattle shoppers to pay 20-cent 'green fee' beginning in 2009 for every new paper or plastic bag they use to carry away goods from grocery, drug or convenience stores; shoppers would be encouraged to bring their own bags for carrying home purchases; foam food containers would also be banned under proposal (M)
snippet: Seattle consumers may face a 20-cent per bag fee under a new proposal, which also would include the banning of foam food containers.

lead_paragraph: IF the American economy is on the brink of meltdown, it's hard to credit it from here. Unemployment in the area is at 3.6 percent, the house-price curve has very slightly dipped but not plunged, and a new business and residential district is climbing fast immediately north of downtown, where the masts and swinging jibs of tower cranes crowd the sky, excavators dig yawning pits in the ground, and men in hard hats swarm over a square mile of concrete, rebar and forsythia-yellow gypsum board. In still-booming Seattle, it's left to the homeless to remind us of economic calamity.

headline.main: Down and Out in America's Last Boomtown

abstract: Jonathan Raban Op-Ed article says economic downturn has not hit Seattle particularly hard yet; says in still-booming Seattle it is homeless population that reminds residents of economic calamity (M)
snippet: If the American economy is on the brink of meltdown, it’s hard to credit it from Seattle.

lead_paragraph: The Baptist church that once stood on a residential corner in this city's Greenwood neighborhood was long ago converted to a Buddhist monastery, pillows in the place of pews. Outside, a bright white stupa stands amid half-million-dollar bungalows, some with signs in their windows reciting current creed: ''Another Neighbor for Peace and Justice.''

headline.main: Dalai Lama Arrives for a Five-Day Conference in Seattle, Very Much His Kind of Town

abstract: Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama arrives in Seattle for five-day conference Seeds of Compassion; plans to speak at University of Washington; Chinese students seek assurances that speech will not arouse anti-China sentiment; photo (M)
snippet: The Dalai Lama’s visit to Seattle is pitch-perfect for an area with one of the country’s lowest rates of church attendance and a notable lack of interest in mainstream American religion.

lead_paragraph: A photograph entered into evidence this week in the trial of Naveed Haq shows an office telephone on a desk at the Jewish Federation of Greater Seattle. Bloodstains are visible on two of the number keys, the 9 and the 1. The person who dialed 911 was one of six federation employees whom Mr. Haq is charged with shooting, one of them fatally, after he forced his way into the group's offices on July 28, 2006. But it was Mr. Haq, whose trial on charges including murder, attempted murder and hate crimes began here this week, who did most of the talking to the 911 operator.

headline.main: Man Is Tried in Gun Attack On Jewish Center in Seattle

abstract: Naveed Haq is on trial in Seattle for murder, attempted murder and hate crimes in July 2006 shooting of six employees of Jewish Federation of Greater Seattle; Haq, who is pleading not guilty by reason of insanity, is on record as telling detectives his action was about Jews; prosecutors accept that he is mentally ill and acted alone; photos (M)
snippet: Prosecutors say the accused is a political extremist who acted deliberately, but that he is mentally ill, so they are not seeking the death penalty.

lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. Board of Governors gave the SuperSonics approval Friday to move to Oklahoma City pending the resolution of litigation that was intended to keep the team at KeyArena in Seattle for the final two seasons of its lease. Only two of the 30 N.B.A. teams, the Dallas Mavericks and the Portland Trail Blazers, voted against the relocation, for which the Sonics will pay the league $30 million.

headline.main: Sonics Given Approval To Move to Oklahoma

abstract: NBA grants Seattle SuperSonics approval to move to Oklahoma City pending resolution of litigation intended to keep team in Seattle (M)
snippet: The SuperSonics will pay the league $30 million to move to Oklahoma City pending the resolution of litigation that was intended to keep the team in Seattle.

lead_paragraph: West Coast ports were shut down on Thursday as thousands of longshoremen failed to report for work, part of what their union leaders said was a one-day, one-shift protest against the war in Iraq. Cranes and forklifts stood still from Seattle to San Diego, and ships were stalled at sea as workers held rallies up and down the coast to blame the war for distracting public attention and money from domestic needs like health care and education.

headline.main: Union's War Protest Shuts West Coast Ports

abstract: West Coast ports are shut down as thousands of longshoremen fail to report for work, part of what their union leaders say is one-day, one-shift protest against war in Iraq; workers hold rallies blaming war for distracting public attention and money from domestic needs; photo (M)
snippet: Workers held rallies up and down the coast, blaming the war for distracting public attention and money from domestic needs like health care and education.

lead_paragraph: People involved in relationships that end abruptly often have grossly conflicting accounts of what went wrong. On Monday, Jerry Yang gave his version. In an interview, Mr. Yang, Yahoo's co-founder and chief executive, addressed Microsoft's surprise $44.6 billion bid to buy his company and the three-month corporate tussle that ensued.

headline.main: Yahoo Chief Says He Was Open to Deal

abstract: Yahoo co-founder and chief executive Jerry Yang says he was open to selling Yahoo to Microsoft, but that Microsoft chief executive Steven A Ballmer and his deal makers ultimately declined to negotiate and withdrew their proposal with little explanation; Yang's account conflicts with that of Microsoft advisers and executives; they say they received no counteroffer from Yahoo for three months, after Microsoft's deadline to consummate deal expired; also say Yang and his board settled on price of $37 per share and ultimately refused to budge; photo (M)
snippet: Jerry Yang said Yahoo was open to Microsoft all along but said he felt that the company he co-founded was simply worth more than what Microsoft put on the table.

byline.original: By BRAD STONE  and MIGUEL HELFT

lead_paragraph: With the price of gas approaching $4 a gallon, more commuters are abandoning their cars and taking the train or bus instead. Mass transit systems around the country are seeing standing-room-only crowds on bus lines where seats were once easy to come by. Parking lots at many bus and light rail stations are suddenly overflowing, with commuters in some towns risking a ticket or tow by parking on nearby grassy areas and in vacant lots.

headline.main: GAS PRICES SEND SURGE OF RIDERS TO MASS TRANSIT

abstract: More commuters are abandoning their cars as price of gas approaches $4 gallon and taking train or bus instead; some cities like New York and Boston have seen increases of ridership of 5 percent or more in 2008; biggest surges--of 10 to 15 percent or more over last year--are occurring in metropolitan areas in South and West; Denver has seen 8 percent increase in ridership in first three months of year compared with last year; transit systems in metropolitan areas like Minneapolis, Seattle, Dallas-Fort Worth and San Francisco report similar jumps; graph; photos (M)
snippet: Cities with long-established public transit systems and areas with a strong driving culture are both reporting increases in ridership on trains and buses.

lead_paragraph: BUSINESS JET BOOM Business jet deliveries, which were at record levels last year, continued to be robust in the first quarter of this year, with 297 shipments, a 40.8 percent increase over the 211 shipped in the first quarter of 2007, according to the General Aviation Manufacturers Association. Last year, 1,138 business jets were delivered to customers in the United States and abroad. MORE MOVES AT HEATHROW British Airways plans to move eight additional long-haul flights into its new Terminal 5 from Terminal 4 at Heathrow Airport on June 5. The increase in flights using Terminal 5 was delayed after the chaotic opening of the terminal in March. The new flights include those between Heathrow and Kennedy International Airport.

headline.main: Memo Pad

abstract: Memo Pad column; General Aviation Manufacturers Assn says there were 297 business jet deliveries in first quarter, 40.8 percent increase over 211 shipped in first quarter of 2007; British Airways plans to move eight additional long-haul flights into its new Terminal 5 from Terminal 4 at Heathrow Airport on June 5; Southwest Airlines is adding three new destinations and five new nonstop routes at Denver International Airport; JetBlue is delaying start of service at Los Angeles International Airport because of rising fuel costs; Korean Air says increases in first- and business-class traffic helped raise first-quarter revenue by 11.5 percent; United Airlines plans to begin nonstop routes between Washington Dulles and Dubai and Moscow on Oct 26; Northwest Airlines plans daily service between Seattle and Beijing beginning March 1 (M)
snippet: News about the airlines.

lead_paragraph: America's home-buying season, when for-sale signs sprout like dandelions, is shaping up to be even worse than expected this year, with prices falling, sales slowing and few signs of a turnaround emerging. Two reports released on Tuesday captured the bleak picture. One showed that home prices nationally fell 14.1 percent in March from a year earlier. The other showed sales of new homes, although up slightly in April, remained mired near their lowest levels since 1991.

headline.main: In Housing, The Strong Turn Weak

abstract: America's home-buying seasons is shaping up to be even worse that expected, with prices falling, sales slowing and few signs of turnaround emerging; Commerce Department reports that sales increased 3.3 percent in April from March, when sales tumbled 11 percent, although increase largely reflects statistical revision to earlier figures; Standard & Poor's Case-Shiller index shows prices of single-family homes have fallen about 6.5 percent from their peak in July 2007 to February; many economists warn that pain in housing market may last for several years; even markets that once seemed immune to slump, like Seattle, are weakening; economists say prices nationwide may fall as much as 10 percent more before recovery takes hold; there are more than 4.5 million homes on market nationwide; way houses are selling, it would take nearly 11 months to clear market; sales figures and prices in various parts of nation discussed; map; graph; photos (L)
snippet: The home-buying season is shaping up to be even worse than expected, with prices falling, sales slowing and few signs of a turnaround.

byline.original: By VIKAS BAJAJ; Christine Haughney contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: THE draw of a neighborhood bracketed by an Interstate and a Superfund-listed river is obscure. That may be what has kept the developers who rounded the rough edges off of other Seattle neighborhoods like Ballard and Fremont out of Georgetown. lead_paragraph: In Ballard, a quiet neighborhood not far from the waterfront where many of its residents once worked, I found a replica of an Icelandic badstofa. I am sure I am not alone in never having seen a badstofa, nor even in knowing what one is. But looking inside at its sharply slanted wooden roof, the large tome open at its far end, the two blond children -- mannequins -- glancing up during a dark night, I began to get some idea.

lead_paragraph: Samuel Snow died refusing to cash the Army's check, but not before receiving a long-awaited apology. Mr. Snow, a retired janitor who was a soldier during World War II, died early Sunday, 64 years after he was wrongly convicted in connection with the death of a prisoner of war at a military post here. At a ceremony on the old post hours before Mr. Snow's death, a top Army official formally apologized to him and to the families of 27 other soldiers who had been involved in the case.

lead_paragraph: Crows and their relatives -- among them ravens, magpies and jays -- are renowned for their intelligence and for their ability to flourish in human-dominated landscapes. That ability may have to do with cross-species social skills. In the Seattle area, where rapid suburban growth has attracted a thriving crow population, researchers have found that the birds can recognize individual human faces. John M. Marzluff, a wildlife biologist at the University of Washington, has studied crows and ravens for more than 20 years and has long wondered if the birds could identify individual researchers. Previously trapped birds seemed more wary of particular scientists, and often were harder to catch. ''I thought, 'Well, it's an annoyance, but it's not really hampering our work,' '' Dr. Marzluff said. ''But then I thought we should test it directly.''

headline.main: Friend or Foe? Crows Never Forget a Face, It Seems

abstract: Dr John M Marzluff, University of Washington wildlife biologist, leads study on ability of crows to recognize human faces; research, which is part of ongoing survey in Seattle area, finds that crows not only have face-recognition abilities, but are able to remember if person is friend or foe and respond appropriately far into future; study used rubber masks to keep facial characteristics consistent during study; photos (M)
snippet: Researchers have found that crows, renowned for their ability to flourish in human-dominated landscapes, can recognize individual human faces.

They added that the show ''continues to be positively received by preview audiences in Seattle,'' according to a report on Playbill.com. The musical version of ''Shrek,'' which stars Brian d'Arcy James, above, is based on the popular DreamWorks film of the same title. Mr. Ashford won a Tony Award in 2002 as the choreographer for ''Thoroughly Modern Millie.''

lead_paragraph: Shara and Scott Di Valerio wanted to build a deck for their hot tub, a place to relax in the woods on their five acres east of Seattle. But at some point, as they found themselves up in a stand of fir trees with a majestic view of Mount Rainier, their perspective shifted. What began as a 12-by-12-foot platform grew into a virtual treehouse complex: hot tub, living room (with phone, cable, Internet), writing alcove, observation platforms. Despite its inviting suspension bridge and 100-foot zipline, this is no kids' tree fort. A typical evening among the gently swaying firs involves several grown-ups, a dip in the hot tub, Champagne and a few rounds of canasta. ''It's a way to be in nature,'' Shara Di Valerio said. She let out a deflating laugh and quickly added: ''Although it's a luxurious kind of nature. It isn't camping.'' The luxury treehouse is a relatively recent phenomenon. Twenty years ago, there was no such thing as a ''master treehouse builder.'' There is now. Thanks to a confluence of eco-conscious clients looking for sustainable hideaways and recent technological advances that allow elaborate structures to be hung higher and more safely than ever, this may be the golden age of the treehouse. There are now more than 10 dedicated builders of adult tree dwellings in the United States. But if any single person is responsible for the treehouse renaissance, it is Peter Nelson. In 1997, he and a partner founded TreeHouse Workshop, a Seattle firm that built a dozen treehouses last year (including the Di Valerios'). ''I started more as a builder,'' Nelson said, ''but I've come to understand that what I'm really after is a place in nature. To be among the trees is pretty powerful stuff.''

headline.main: Up, Up and Away

lead_paragraph: Each year food waste makes up more than 30 percent of Seattle's garbage -- about 150,000 tons. A new program is expected to cut that by more than half. Starting in April, all single-family homes in the the city will be required to subscribe to a weekly food-waste recycling program. ''The main change is in what we call organics,'' said Timothy Croll, the solid-waste director of the public-utilities department in Seattle. In addition to vegetative waste and food-contaminated paper (like paper towels or plates), people will also be able to recycle meat and dairy products.The recycled waste will be used as compost for parks and gardens. By 2012, Seattle aspires to recycle 60 percent of its waste; up from the 48.7 percent of waste now diverted from the landfill. ''If we keep it out of the landfill,'' Croll says, ''we'll save money on our disposable costs. We can reuse resources rather than using fresh, virgin sources.'' S. KIRK WALSH

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE -- It was not your usual courtroom scene. For one thing, the judge choked up as he described one woman's struggle with opiate addiction after her arrest for forging prescriptions. Over the last three years, she had repeatedly missed court-ordered therapy and hearings, and the judge, J. Wesley Saint Clair of the Drug Diversion Court, at first meted out mild punishments, like community service. But last winter, pushed past his forgiving limit, he jailed her briefly twice. The threat of more jail did the trick.
